    Flexible BODIPY Platform That Offers an Unexpected Regioselective Heterocyclization Reaction toward Preparation of 2-Pyridone[a]-Fused BODIPYs

    • Natalia O. Didukh
      Natalia O. Didukh
      Institute of Organic Chemistry, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 5 Murmanska str., 02660 Kyiv, Ukraine
      Department of Chemistry, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB R3T 2N2, Canada
      More by Natalia O. Didukh

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    We have explored the synthetic routes for regioselective formation of 2-pyridone[a]- and 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs using 1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-BODIPY as the universal starting platform. While heterocyclization of the 3-(dimethylaminovinyl)-BODIPY and 3,5-bis(dimethylaminovinyl)-BODIPY results in the formation of mono-2-pyridone- and bis-2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs, respectively, similar heterocyclization of the 1,3-bis(dimethylaminovinyl)-BODIPY leads to the regioselective formation of the 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY core, which is the first example of heterocycle[a]-fused BODIPYs. The regioselective formation of the 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY was further confirmed by X-ray crystallography and explained on the basis of the DFT and TDDFT calculations that are suggestive of the energy-favorable out-of-plane rotation of the dimethylaminovinyl group located at first position, which accelerates the reaction with n-butylamine. Trends in the UV–vis and fluorescence spectra of the BODIPYs 1–17 were discussed on the basis of DFT and TDDFT calculations.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Dyes derived from a boron dipyrromethene (4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene or BODIPY) have been attracting considerable attention over the past decades because of their excellent thermal, chemical, and photochemical stability, high molar absorption coefficients, high fluorescence quantum yields, tunable optical properties, and a large two-photon cross section for multiphoton excitation. (1−13) Tuning the optical and redox properties of the BODIPYs requires development of a large scope of synthetic procedures for regioselective chemical modification at specific position(s) of the BODIPY core. Not surprisingly, a variety of the chemical transformations of the BODIPY core that include formylation, (14,15) Knoevenagel condensation, (16−19) halogenation, (20−22) cyanination, (23−25) nucleophilic substitution, (26,27) coupling, (28−30) and substitution at the boron hub (31−33) have been developed in recent years. One of the most effective synthetic strategies that allows incremental optical tuning of the optical properties of BODIPY system is the annulation of the BODIPY core using α,β- ([b]-fused BODIPYs) or β,β′-carbon atoms ([a]-fused BODIPYs) that can be fused with either aromatic benzene or heterocyclic rings. (34,35) Such benzo- or heterocyclic fusion leads to the formation of a rigid, extended π-system with different optical and tunable fluorescence properties. For instance, simultaneous benzo-[b]-fusion of the BODIPY core (I, Chart 1) leads to the red shift of the most intense, low-energy BODIPY transition with a dramatic reduction of both the molar extinction coefficient and fluorescence quantum yield when compared to the parent BODIPY. (36,37) In contrast, prepared by Suzuki and co-workers, (38,39) furan-[b]-fused BODIPY II (known as Keio Fluors) exhibits a very strong fluorescence and similar to a BODIPY I low-energy optical shift with a very large intensity increase. To date, a large array of such type dyes have been obtained. (40−53) Additional benzoannulation of II with one (III) or two (IV) conjugated benzene rings leads to a further red shift of the low-energy BODIPY transition that is accompanied by a significant reduction of the fluorescence quantum yields. (54)
    In our previous work, we have demonstrated that the BODIPY core V (Chart 1) provides a very high degree of flexibility for tuning its redox, optical, and fluorescence properties. (23,24,55−63) Indeed, active α-methyl groups in V can be easily introduced to Knoevenagel condensation (61−63) as well as formylation reaction. (55) In the latter case, mono- and bis-diacetaldehyde derivatives can be used for cyclocondensation reactions with an ester group or boron hub. (55−60) In particular, heterocyclization reaction with an ester group results in the formation of mono- or bis(2-pyridone)-containing BODIPYs (BODIPY VI, Chart 1). (64) Unlike benzo-analogue I, BODIPY VI is highly fluorescent, has an intense BODIPY-centered low-energy transition, and compared to I and II undergoes the largest red shift, which is close to BODIPY III. Moreover, a further significant decrease in the optical gap of BODIPY VI can be achieved by the introduction of the cyano group into its meso-position. (23,24)
    Compared to the benzo[b]-fusion, the benzo[a]-fusion leads to the “isoindole” type BODIPY chromophore (for instance BODIPY VII) that has a further red-shifted (compared to the parent BODIPY I) BODIPY absorption of higher intensity and a much higher fluorescence quantum yield. (34,65−73) The heterocyclic analogues of “isoindole” type BODIPYs VII are unknown, and thus the difference between optical properties of the homologue series of [a]-fused and [b]-fused heterocyclic BODIPYs has not been evaluated. Since phenyl groups in BODIPY platform V preclude any heterocyclization reactions needed for [a]-fusion, we were hoping that its tetramethyl-containing analogue 1 (Scheme 1) can be used for the formation of 2-pyridone[a]-fused and 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs that would allow us, for the first time, to investigate the influence of the fusion position on the optical properties of the heterocycle-containing BODIPY core. Although BODIPY core 1 has been known since 1968, (74) it was not intensively used as a starting platform for BODIPY core modification perhaps because of its relatively low stability in chemical reactions. To our great surprise, discussed below, the 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY core results in a larger, not smaller, optical gap, which is in contrast with general trends for benzo[a]-fused and benzo[b]-fused BODIPYs I and VII (Chart 1).

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The initial rationale for using tetramethyl-containing BODIPY 1 was to explore and compare the reactivity of the methyl groups at the 1,7- versus 3,5-positions. Although 1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-BODIPY 1 has been known since 1968, (74) to our surprise, this platform was mentioned only in four publications to date. (74−77) Moreover, while the chemical transformations of the diphenyl-analogue V are quite well-explored, only a single paper on BODIPY 1 discussed direct nitromethylation of its meso-position and thus the reactivity of the four methyl groups in 1 remains completely unexplored. (75) This is even more surprising taking into consideration commercial availability and ease of preparation of the 2,4-dimethyl-3-carbethoxypyrrole, which is a key precursor for synthesis of BODIPY 1. Thus, we carefully explored the chemistry of the BODIPY 1. First, we tested a standard Knoevenagel reaction between BODIPY 1 and several aromatic aldehydes since up to four methyl groups can be involved in the condensation reaction. (78−80) To our surprise, under typical Knoevenagel reaction conditions (piperidine/acetic acid in boiling benzene or toluene) BODIPY 1 undergoes fast degradation with elimination of the chromophoric π-system. In a separate control experiment, it was found that the BODIPY 1 even in a piperidine/acetic acid/solvent system (no aldehyde added) loses the BF2 fragment and undergoes slow degradation, which contrasts with chemistry established for a stable BODIPY V. Further control experiments have shown that the BODIPY 1 is quite sensitive toward organic and inorganic bases which narrows the scope of the chemical reactions accessible for 1 and might explain the lack of reports that explore the chemistry of this BODIPY core. The relatively low stability of the BODIPY 1 cannot be explained by electronic effects, as the more electron-donating methyl groups in 1 should stabilize this core toward deborylation reaction compared to V, which is not the case. Although one might speculate that the partial conjugation of the phenyl groups in V can be responsible for its higher stability (the torsion angle between the phenyl group and the pyrrolic heterocycle in available X-ray crystal structures of 1,7-diphenyl substituted BODIPYs varies between 39.8° and 56.8°), at this time we have no clear proof of this hypothesis.
    Despite the lower stability and sensitivity of BODIPY 1 toward bases, it still can be involved in a variety of chemical transformations that results in preparation of 2-pyridone[b]-fused and more importantly 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPYs outlined in Schemes 1–3. Indeed, the reaction between BODIPY 1 and DMF dimethyl acetal conducted under mild conditions results in the formation of enamine-containing BODIPY 2 (Scheme 1). Hydrolysis of the BODIPY 2 in acidic media leads to the formation of aldehyde 3, which is unlike its 1,7-diphenyl analogue V (55) which exists only as an aldehyde (no enol tautomeric form was observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of 3). Reaction between aldehyde 3 and n-butylamine in chloroform at room temperature leads to the formation of enamine 4, which undergoes heterocyclization reaction and forms the target BODIPY 5. BODIPY 5 can also be prepared by the direct reaction between enamine 2 and n-butylamine in acetonitrile but with significantly lower yield (Scheme 1).
    Next, we expected that the monopyridone-containing BODIPY 5 can be further transformed into dipyridone BODIPY 11 (Scheme 2) by a second aminoformylation reaction with the remaining 5-methyl group in 5 that would follow chemistry similar to that outlined in Scheme 1 and proven in the formation of the dipyridone derivative of BODIPY V. (58) However, the reaction between BODIPY 5 and DMF dimethyl acetal was found to produce several unstable dyes that cannot be separated by conventional methods in reasonable yields. Thus, the target BODIPY 11 was prepared according to a general synthetic approach (56) outlined in Scheme 2. All synthetic steps shown in Scheme 2 proceed smoothly and allow preparation of the target BODIPY 11 in a reasonable yield. Again, aldehydes 8 and 10 that were prepared by stepwise hydrolysis of BODIPYs 7 and 9, respectively, exist entirely in aldehyde tautomeric form without any detection by NMR spectroscopy of the enol tautomeric form. We also tried to form bis-2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPY 11 directly from 9 (that can be obtained in a single step from 7) without much success.
    During preparation of the enamine 2 from BODIPY 1 we always observed the formation of an unknown byproduct. In order to minimize this impurity, the reaction should be conducted under mild temperature (boiling DCE, dichloroethane) so the impurity can be removed from the reaction product by a simple recrystallization. However, when starting BODIPY 1 was reacted with DMF dimethyl acetal at higher temperature (boiling toluene), we obtained an unexpected bis-enamine 12 as a single pure product (Scheme 3). No formation of tris- or tetrakis-enamine containing BODIPYs was observed in this reaction. Initial analysis of the NMR and UV–vis spectra of 12 was inconclusive. Indeed, two different enamine fragments can be clearly seen in the 1H NMR spectrum of 12. However, the NMR spectrum of 12 does not differentiate between 1,3- and 1,5-regioisomers. Further hydrolysis of bis-enamine 12 in acidic conditions results in dialdehyde 13, which also has two different aldehyde signals in the 1H NMR spectrum, which again does not differentiate between 1,3- and 1,5-regioisomers. Room-temperature reaction of bis-enamine 12 with an excess of n-butylamine in acetonitrile results in formation of BODIPY 14, which upon prolonged reaction time (3 days) transforms into BODIPY 15 (Scheme 3). In order to clarify structures of BODIPYs 12–15, we have tried to grow corresponding single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis. Although, in a majority of cases, single crystals turned out to be too small for a single-crystal data collection, we were able to obtain a crystal structure of BODIPY 14 that clarified the unusual reactivity of the BODIPY 1.
    The X-ray analysis of BODIPY 14 (Figure 1) is clearly indicative of the regioselective formation of 1,3-bis-enamine 12, which upon heterocyclization forms 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY 14. The X-ray structure of 14 is indicative of the planar BODIPY core and essentially coplanar with the BODIPY enamine fragment. The C═O bond in the pyridone fragment of 14 has clear double bond character and forms a short hydrogen bond with the hydrogen atom of the enamine group. The B–F and B–N bond distances were found to be typical for the BODIPYs range. The −C(pyrr)–CH═, −CH═CH–, and ═CH–N– bond distances in 14 are clearly indicative of the enamine fragment π-delocalization rather then classic alternation of single and double bonds.
    Thus, a second aminoformylation reaction that transforms BODIPY 1 via 2 into bis-enamine 12 is regioselective and dictates formation of the regioselective products 13–17 (Scheme 3). The regioselective formation of 1,3-bis-enamine product 12 is very unusual and contradicts current understanding of the BODIPY’s chemistry. Indeed, it is generally accepted that the methyl groups at the α-positions (3,5-positions) of the BODIPY core have higher reactivity of the C–H bonds compared to the methyl groups located at the β-positions (1,7-positions) of the BODIPY core. (78−80) At this moment, we do not have a clear explanation on the regioselective formation of the BODIPY 12. Indeed, DFT calculations on BODIPY 2 (monoenamine compound) are indicative of very similar Mulliken charges on carbon as well as hydrogen atoms in all three remaining methyl groups although one might speculate that the Mulliken charge on the most acidic proton of the methyl group at position 1 (+0.245) is slightly higher than that at position 5 (+0.241) and position 7 (+0.237). Similarly, the DFT-predicted Mulliken charge at the methyl group carbon atom located at position 1 of the BODIPY core in BODIPY 2 (−0.662) is slightly lower than that at positions 5 (−0.705) and 7 (−0.669).
    Unusual regioselective formation of the BODIPY 14 from bis-enamine 12 can be explained more easily. Indeed, the 1H NMR spectrum of BODIPY 12 is indicative of two quite different enamine groups (Figure 2). One set of signals (in particular doublets at 8.3 and 6.2 ppm) is almost identical to that observed in the monoenamine 2 (Supporting Information) and was assigned to the enamine fragment located at position 3 (α-position) of the BODIPY core. Two doublets at 5.9 and 7.0 ppm belong to the −CH═CH– protons of the second enamine fragment located at position 1 (β-position) of the BODIPY core. Similarly, two different enamine fragments were observed in DMSO-d6, but in this solvent the observed differences in chemical shifts are smaller (Figure 2). A conformational search on the potential energy surface of BODIPY 12 reveals the presence of four conformers with ∼65:25:9:1% contributions at room temperature (Figure 3). The NMR DFT calculations on the most stable conformation of 12 suggest that the ═C(H)–N proton at position 3 (predicted at 9.29 ppm) should be quite different from that located at position 1 (predicted at 6.98 ppm).
    In two major conformers that account for ∼90% contribution, the enamine fragment at position 1 (β-position) is rotated away from the BODIPY plane by ∼30° (Figure 3), while the second enamine fragment remains almost coplanar with the BODIPY core. In this case, one might expect a considerably higher reactivity of the nonconjugated enamine toward nucleophilic attack by an excess of n-butylamine, which explains the fast and regioselective formation of BODIPY 14. Further reaction of the BODIPY 14 with an excess of n-butylamine results in the formation of BODIPY 15. The lower reactivity of the better conjugated enamine fragment in BODIPY 12 at position 3 (α-position) correlates well with that observed in BODIPY 2 (Scheme 1), as, in both cases, a cross-enamination reaction with n-butylamine requires harsher reaction conditions.
    A higher reactivity of the enamine fragment at position 1 (β-position) in BODIPY 12 allowed us to prepare first heterocycle[a]-fused (“isoindole” type) BODIPYs 14–17, which can be directly compared with more common heterocycle[b]-fused (“indole” type) BODIPYs. Indeed, the remaining enamine fragment in BODIPY 14 can be transformed into the methyl group of BODIPY 17 by stepwise hydrolysis followed by the deformylation reaction in ethylene glycol (Scheme 3). Although target BODIPY 17 can be prepared in this synthetic pathway, the yield of the final product is rather low and we were not able to find reaction conditions that improve its preparation. Moreover, our attempts to prepare bis-2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY from 17 have also failed.
    Optical properties of the new BODIPYs are summarized in Table 1 with typical examples shown in Figures 4–6. For the majority of BODIPYs modified at positions 3 and 5 (α-positions), the energy of the characteristic and the most intense BODIPY band in the visible region correlates well with the properties of 1,7-diphenyl-containing analogues based on BODIPY platform V (Chart 1) with the exception of aldehydes 3, 8, 10, and 13 which exhibit UV–vis spectra indistinguishable from methyl analogues. The observed difference for the 1,7-dimethyl BODIPY aldehydes 3, 8, 10, and 13 compared to the 1,7-diphenyl analogues can be attributed to the pure aldehyde tautomeric form observed in the former cases and predominantly enol tautomeric form observed in the latter compounds. In the case of disubstituted BODIPYs the low-energy shift of the most intense BODIPY band has an additive nature as shown in Figure 4 for BODIPYs 2 and 9.
    Table 1. Photophysical Properties of BODIPYs 1–17 in DCM
    no.λabs, nmε, M–1·cm–1Δλabs, nmaλem, nmΦf, %
    150492 000–51493
    260367 00099632<1
    350289 000–251480
    459270 00088628<1
    556184 0005758274
    653476 0003055670
    762945 000125680<1
    853572 0003154960
    970576 000201750<1
    1050268 000–251595
    11623103 00011965281
    1258759 000183––
    1350474 000051584
    1458354 0008161045
    1557760 0007360280
    1654070 0003655485
    1753578 0003154896
    a

    Spectral shift in comparison with BODIPY 1.

    It is interesting to note that unlike all other BODIPYs mentioned in this work, the 1,3-bisenamine 12 is fairly solvatochromic (Figure 5). Moreover, a relative intensity of the higher-energy band observed at ∼540 nm increases with an increase of solvent polarity, which is explained below on the basis of TDDFT calculations.
    Comparison of the UV–vis spectra of isomeric 2-pyridone[a]-fused and 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs 17 and 5 is rather interesting. Indeed, benzo[a]-fused BODIPY VII has significantly red-shifted the characteristic BODIPY band compared to the [b]-fused analogue I. In contrast, 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY 17 has a blue-shifted low-energy band compared to the isomeric BODIPY 5 (Table 1 and Figure 6), and this difference is explained below on the basis of DFT and TDDFT calculations. It is also interesting to compare an influence of the enamine fragment at position 3 on the low-energy shift in BODIPYs 1, 2, and 4 versus their 2-pyridone[a]-fused analogues 17, 14, and 15 (Table 1). For the ester-containing 1, 2, and 4, introduction of the enamine fragment into position 3 results in a large (3255 cm–1 for 1–2 pair and 2950 cm–1 for 1–4 pair) low-energy shift of the most intense BODIPY band, while similar shifts are about twice as small in the 17–14 pair (1535 cm–1) and 17–15 pair (1360 cm–1). Our initial thought was that the formation of a rigid seven-member hydrogen-bonded cycle in 2-pyridone[a]-fused BOIPYs 14 and 15 would force the enamine fragment slightly out of the BODIPY plane, which would reduce conjugation and thus will lead to a smaller red shift of the first BODIPY transition in these compounds compared to more conformationally flexible BODIPYs 2 and 4 in which the enamine fragment can adopt coplanarity with the BODIPY core geometry, better conjugation, and thus a larger red shift. However, our DFT calculations (as well as X-ray crystallographic results for BODIPY 14) do not support such a hypothesis. Indeed, the DFT-predicted −C=O---H–C═ torsion angles for BODIPYs 14 and 15 (1.92° and 2.36°, respectively) correlate well with X-ray data on 14 (4.20°) and are close to those predicted for BODIPYs 2 and 4 (2.47° and 2.45°, respectively). Similarly, DFT predicts that the C(β-pyrr)–C(α-pyrr)–C(α-enamine)–C(β-enamine) torsion angles in 2 and 4 (7.34° and 7.71°, respectively) should be larger than those in in BODIPYs 14 and 15 (0.59° and 1.04°, respectively), and thus better conjugation between the enamine fragment and BODIPY core is expected for pyridone-containing BODIPYs 14 and 15. DFT calculations also predict that the formation of the six-membered pyridone heterocycle would bring a carbonyl oxygen atom closer to the C–H proton in the −CH═CH– enamine fragment in BODIPYs 14 and 15 (1.958 and 1.961 Å, respectively) compared to the longer distances in BODIPYs 2 and 4 (1.962 and 1.966 Å, respectively). The presence of the shorter hydrogen bond in pyridone-containing BODIPYs 14 and 15 was further confirmed by the 1H NMR spectroscopy in which a ═C(H)–N signal originated from the proton located next to the nitrogen atom in BODIPYs 14 and 15 was observed as a broad singlet, while a similar signal in BODIPYs 2 and 4 was observed as a well-resolved multiplet (Supporting Information).
    The fluorescence properties of the target BODIPYs are summarized in Table 1 while representative spectra are shown in Figure 7. The fluorescence in enamine-containing BODIPYs 2, 4, 7, 9, and 12 is almost quenched as expected for systems with significant (2, 4, 7, and 9) or predominant (12) contributions from the enamine fragment(s) to the HOMO. In contrast, fluorescence quantum yields of aldehyde-containing BODIPYs are high (Table 1). Both 2-pyridone[a]-fused and 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs 17, 5, and 11 have high fluorescence quantum yields. Surprisingly, enamine-containing 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPYs 14 and 15 also have high fluorescence quantum yields (Table 1). Our DFT and TDDFT calculations are indicative of rather unusual electronic structures and the nature of the excited states in these compounds that are responsible for their high fluorescence quantum yields.
    In order to understand photophysical properties of the new BODIPYs, we have conducted DFT and TDDFT calculations of all systems of interest. The molecular orbital diagram is shown in Figure 8, frontier orbitals are the pictures in Figure 9, and molecular orbital compositions of enamine BODIPYs are presented in Figure 10. First, DFT-predicted energies for the HOMO and LUMO in BODIPY-aldehydes 3, 10, and 13 are almost identical, which reflects their close energies in characteristic BODIPY band observed at 502–504 nm in these compounds. Interestingly, the HOMO–1 in aldehydes 3, 8, 10, and 13 is localized at the aldehyde fragment, which is suggestive of the dominance of the aldehyde versus enol form in these compounds that agrees well with the NMR data discussed above. Similarly, DFT-predicted energies of the HOMO in BODIPYs 2, 4, 7, 14, and 15 that have a single enamine group at position 3 are close to each other. DFT-predicted destabilization of the HOMO follows the trend 2 ≈ 4 ≈ 7 ≈ 14 ≈ 15 < 12 < 9, which reflects the cumulative electron-donating properties of the enamine groups at BODIPY cores. It was not surprising to see that the HOMO energy in 12 is only slightly higher in energy than the HOMO in 2 or 4, as it might be expected that the influence of a poorly conjugated enamine group that is attached to the β-pyrrolic position (position with lower contribution into the HOMO compared to the α-pyrrolic carbon) would be rather small. DFT predicts that the HOMO energy in [b]- and [a]-fused BODIPYs 5 and 17 should be close to each other, while the LUMO in 17 should have a higher energy compared to the LUMO in 5. A significantly larger contribution from the electron-withdrawing pyridone fragment to the LUMO in 5 compared to that in 17 might be a primarily reason for its stabilization. The DFT-predicted HOMO–LUMO energy gap in bispyridone BODIPY 11 compared to the monopyridone-containing BODIPYs 5 and 17 correlate well with the lower-energy BODIPY transition observed for this compound. The DFT-predicted HOMO–1 in bisenamine 12 as well as pyridone-containing BODIPYs 13–15 is localized over the substituents rather than the BODIPY core (Figures 9 and 10), which creates a possibility of the HOMO–1 → LUMO low-energy intramolecular charge-transfer (ICT) transitions that are discussed below. In the case of 1,3-bisenamine BODIPY 12, the HOMO has close to equal contribution of two enamine fragments, while HOMO–1 is dominated by the contribution from the enamine group located at position 1 (β-position).
    The TDDFT approach was used for the prediction of the vertical excitation energies in BODIPYs 1–17 (Figure 11). TDDFT calculations indicate that the most intense low-energy transition in BODIPYs 1–17 is π–π* in nature and dominated by a single HOMO → LUMO single electron excitation (Supporting Information). TDDFT also correctly reproduced trends in the energies of the first excited states in 2-pyridone-containing BODIPYs 5, 11, and 17. In particular, TDDFT confirms that the blue shift in the BODIPY-centered low-energy band in 17 compared to 5 is associated with a large HOMO–LUMO energy gap in the former BODIPY, which is in contrast with the analogous data for benzo-fused BODIPYs I and VII (Chart 1). Such a blue shift is reflective of the electron-withdrawing nature of pyridone fragment in BODIPYs 5 and 17. As was mentioned above, the reason for a larger HOMO–LUMO energy gap in BODIPY 17 is greater stabilization of the LUMO by 2-pyridone[b] fusion in 5 compared to the 2-pyridone[a] fusion in 17. In contrast, the electron-donating nature of the benzene-fused fragments in I and VII should cause an opposite effect, i.e., an increase of the HOMO–LUMO energy gap in [b]-fused I compared to [a]-fused VII, which correlate well with the experimental data on these compounds. (36,37,65) TDDFT calculations also accurately predicted a red shift of the first excited state in bispyridone BODIPY 11 compared to BODIPY 5 as well as a small blue shift between enamine-BODIPYs 2 and 4 and 14 and 15 (Figure 11). The blue shift in [a]-fused BODIPYs 14 and 15 compared to the enamine-BODIPYs 2 and 4 is also well-reproduced by TDDFT calculations. Finally, TDDFT also correctly predicted trends in transition energies for enamines 2, 9, and 12 indicating that the first transition state energy increases as 9 < 2 < 12 and addition of the second enamine group at position 1 in 1,3-bisenamine BODIPY 12 has a very minor influence on the energy of the first excited state compared to BODIPY 2. Finally, TDDFT calculations allowed us to explain the solvatochromic behavior of the BODIPY 12 and observable fluorescence in pyridone-BODIPYs 14 and 15. Indeed, TDDFT predicts that the ICT band in 1,3-bisenamine BODIPY 12 is a second excited state that lies only 0.326 eV higher in energy compared to the BODIPY centered first excited state (Figure 11). Thus, a low-energy visible part of the UV–vis spectrum of BODIPY 12 should be dominated by a superposition of the BODIPY-centered π–π* and ICT transitions. Since an ICT transition is expected to be more sensitive to the solvent polarity compared to the π–π* transition, one might expect the larger changes in the spectrum profile associated with the higher energy part of the spectral envelope, which is, indeed, observed experimentally (Figure 5). The closeness in energy of the ICT and π–π* transitions in BODIPY 12 is also responsible for the nearly complete fluorescence quenching in this compound. On the other hand, the TDDFT-predicted energy difference between π–π* and ICT transitions in pyridone-BODIPYs 14 and 15 (0.728 and 0.726 eV, respectively) is too large for the effective ICT-driven fluorescence quenching in these systems and thus BODIPYs 14 and 15 have high fluorescence quantum yields. A similar trend has recently been observed in pyridine analogues of phthalocyanines. (81) The ICT-based fluorescent quenching is not applicable to the other enamine-containing BODIPYs, as they do not have enamine-centered localized MOs in the HOMO region. Overall, DFT and TDDFT calculations on BODIPYs 1–17 are in good agreement with the experimental data and explains all experimental trends in their UV–vis and fluorescence spectra.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this report, we have discussed the detailed reactivity of 1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-BODIPY 1. It was found that the BODIPY 1 is rather sensitive to the organic bases, which restricts its usage in the standard Knoevenagel reactions. However, BODIPY 1 can be used as a starting platform for dimethylamino formylation reactions that result in rather unusual chemistry. In particular, we found synthetic strategies that regioselectively transform BODIPY 1 into 2-pyridone[a]- and 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPYs 17 and 5 which allowed us direct comparison between heterocycle-fused BODIPY systems. 2-Pyridone[a]-fused BODIPYs 17 is the first example of the heterocycle[a]-fused BODIPY. Unlike benzo analogues of BODIPYs I and VII, 2-pyridone[a]-fused BODIPY 17 has a higher-energy first excited state compared to the 2-pyridone[b]-fused BODIPY 5. DFT and TDDFT calculations were used to explain photophysical trends in BODIPYs 1–17.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Spectroscopy Measurements

    Absorption spectra were recorded with a Shimadzu UV-3100 spectrophotometer. 1H NMR (400 MHz, 25 °C, TMS as an internal standard), 13C NMR (125 MHz), 19F NMR (376 MHz), and 11B NMR (128 MHz) spectra were obtained with a Bruker Avance 400 and a Bruker Avance 500 instrument. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Solar CM 2203 fluorescence spectrophotometer (measurement range 300–820 nm). The emission spectra were corrected for wavelength dependence of the detector. The relative fluorescent quantum yields (Φf) were determined using Cy5 (Φf = 0.25, EtOH) and Nile blue (Φf = 0.27, EtOH) as the references. High-resolution mass spectra of compounds 2–17 were recorded using a Bruker micrOTOF-QIII.

    Computational Details

    The starting geometries of compounds 1–17 were optimized using a TPSSh exchange-correlation functional. (82) Energy minima in optimized geometry were confirmed by the frequency calculations (absence of the imaginary frequencies). The solvent effect was calculated using the polarized continuum model (PCM). (83) In all calculations, DCM was used as the solvent. In PCM-TDDFT calculations, the first 30 states were calculated. All atoms were modeled using the 6-311G(d) (84) basis set. Gaussian 09 software was used in all calculations. (85) The QMForge program was used for molecular orbital analysis. (86)

    X-ray Crystallography

    Single crystals of BODIPY 14 suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained by slow evaporation from their DCM/methanol solutions. X-ray diffraction data for 14 were collected on a Rigaku RAPID II Image Plate system using graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54187 Å) at 123 K. All diffractometer manipulations, including data collection, integration, and scaling, were carried out using the Bruker APEX3 software suite. (87) Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS.
    Crystal data for 14 C25H31B1F2N4O3·C7H8: MW = 576.48, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 15.1030(5) Å, b = 12.2789(3) Å, c = 16.4063(12) Å, β = 95.270(7)°, V = 3029.7(3) Å3, Z = 4, μ = 0.732 mm–1, 17 365 reflections, (1392 I > 2σ(I)), θmax = 58.936; final R1 = 0.0948, Rw(all) = 0.2199. Additional crystallographic information for all compounds may be found in the CIF included as Supporting Information or accessible from the Cambridge Structural Database: CCDC-1882628.

    Synthesis

    3-(2-Dimethylaminoethen-1-yl)-1,5,7-trimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacene (2)

    The mixture of BODIPY 1 (10 g, 0.025 mol) and DMF dimethyl acetal (8.97 g, 0.075 mol) in 1,2-dicloroethane (500 mL) was refluxed for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was washed with water, dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated to dryness. The crude product was recrystallized from acetonitrile and filtered to give 8.5 g (74.5%) of BODIPY 2.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.45 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 6.94 (s, 1H), 6.25 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 4.36–4.27 (m, 4H), 3.23–3.34 (m, 6H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.43–2.42 (m, 6H), 1.41–1.35 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3, 125 MHz) δ: 165.4, 164.9, 158.9, 154.6, 152.2, 147.8, 136.8, 134.9, 130.5, 121.4, 117.5, 113.6, 88.3, 60.4, 59.5, 43.5, 14.4, 12.2, 11.7; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −143.43 (q, J = 33.84 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.58 (t, J = 35.2 Hz). HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C22H27BF2N3O4 446.2068; found 446.2091.

    (1,5,7-Trimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacen-3-yl)acetaldehyde (3)

    The suspension of compound 2 (0.4 g, 0.89 mmol) was heated at 100 °C in 40% aqueous acetic acid (10 mL) for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into water and filtrated. The crude product was recrystallized from toluene and filtered to give 0.34 g (90%) of 3 as a dark red solid.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.73 (s, 1H), 7.47 (s, 1H), 4.40 (s, 2H), 4.34–4.27 (m, 4H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.50 (s, 6H), 1.40–1.32 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 195.5, 163.7, 163.6, 163.2, 153.0, 148.2, 144.7, 134.0, 132.8, 124.4, 121.8, 120.8, 60.4, 43.4, 15.2, 14.3, 14.2, 12.1, 11.9; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −141.88 (q, J = 33.84 Hz). 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.07(t, J = 32.6 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C20H22BF2N2O5 419.1599; found 419.1623.

    3-(2-Butylaminoethen-1-yl)-1,5,7-trimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacene (4)

    To the solution of compound 3 (1.8 g, 4.27 mmol) in chloroform (100 mL), acetic acid (0.5 g, 8.55 mmol) was added. Then the solution of n-BuNH2 (0.34 g in 5 mL of CHCl3, 4.7 mmol) was slowly added. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 20 min. Then the organic layer was washed with water, dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated to dryness. The crude product was recrystallized from CCl4 and filtered to give 1.9 g (93%) of 4 as a violet solid.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.45–8.40 (m, 1H), 6.98 (s, 1H), 6.42 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 5.18 (bs, 1H), 4.36–4.27 (m, 4H), 3.33 (q, J = 6 Hz, 2H), 2.78 (s, 3H), 2.44–2.42 (m, 6H), 1.65–1.58 (m, 2H), 1.43–1.35 (m, 8H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 165.3, 164.9, 153.0, 147.6, 136.5, 130.6, 117.8, 114.6, 60.5, 59.6, 20.0, 14.5, 14.4, 13.7, 12.2, 11.8; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −143.35–143.63 (m). 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.50 (t, J = 35.0 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C24H31BF2N3O4 474.2386; found 474.2404.

    2-Carbethoxy-7-(1-butyl)-1,3,9-trimethyl-4,4-difluoro-3a,4a,7-triaza-4-bora-cyclopenta[b]fluoren-8-on (5)

    Method A
    The mixture of compound 4 (1.7 g, 3.57 mmol) and 1 M aqueous solution of AcONa (0.2 mL) in isopropanol (50 mL) was refluxed overnight. The mixture was cooled down to room temperature, and the resulting precipitate was filtered off. The crude product was recrystallized from toluene and filtered to give 0.950 g (60%) of pure compound 5 as a dark red solid.
    Method B
    The mixture of compound 2 (4 g, 8.9 mmol) and n-butylamine (12 g, 164 mmol) in acetonitrile (40 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 40 min. Then the reaction mixture was poured into 10% aqueous acetic acid, and the resulting precipitate was filtered off. The crude product was recrystallized from toluene and filtered to give 1.6 g (42%) of compound 5 as a dark red solid.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.20 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.62 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.37 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 3.92 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.87 (s, 3H), 2.73 (s, 3H), 2.54 (s, 3H), 1.75–1.67 (m, 2H), 1.41–1.38 (m, 5H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 163.7, 162.8, 160.0, 152.2, 147.5, 143.2, 139.2, 135.1, 123.4, 121.9, 120.2, 97.2, 60.4, 48.2, 31.7, 20.0, 15.3, 14.3, 13.7, 12.1, 11.3; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −144.42 (q, J = 33.84 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 0.94 (t, J = 32 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C22H25BF2N3O3 428.1967; found 428.1984.

    3-(2-Acetoxyethen-1-yl)-1,5,7-trimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacene (6)

    The mixture of compound 3 (2.42 g, 5.75 mmol) and DMF dimethyl acetal (0.462 g, 6.32 mmol) in Ac2O (15 mL) was heated at 110 °C for 2 h. Then the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and diluted with Et2O, and the resulting precipitate was collected by filtration to give 1.78 g (66%) of pure compound 6.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.68 (d, J = 12.5 Hz, 1H), 7.36 (s, 1H), 7.08 (d, J = 12.5 Hz, 1H), 4.37–4.30 (m, 4H), 2.83 (s, 3H), 2.51 (s, 3H), 2.47 (s, 3H), 2.23 (s, 3H), 1.38 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 167.2, 164.0, 163.9, 161.6, 152.1, 146.7, 146.1, 145.2, 133.8, 133.4, 122.6, 121.2, 120.9, 105.0, 60.8, 60.3, 20.7, 15.1, 14.3, 14.2, 12.1; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −143.35–143.63 (m); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 0.94 (t, J = 34.9 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C22H24BF2N2O6 461.1705; found 461.1721.

    3-(2-Acetoxyethen-1-yl)-5-(2-dimethylaminoethen-1-yl)-1,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diazas-indacene (7)

    The mixture of BODIPY 6 (1.78 g, 3.82 mmol), DMF dimethyl acetal (2.28 g, 19.1 mmol), and Ac2O (3.95g, 38.2 mmol) in toluene (35 mL) was refluxed for 3 min. After the mixture cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered off and dried to give 1.19 g (60%) of compound 7.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.65 (d, J = 12.8 Hz, 1H), 8.60 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 1H), 7.19 (d, J = 12.8 Hz, 1H), 6.86 (s, 1H), 6.32 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 1H), 4.35–4.32 (m, 4H), 3.30 (s, 3H), 3.05 (s, 3H), 2.41 (s, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 2.18 (s, 3H), 1.40–1.36 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ 167.7, 165.4, 164.8, 159.2, 155.8, 148.0, 143.0, 137.9, 134.2, 132.1, 122.5, 118.6, 111.9, 105.6, 88.4, 77.4, 77.2, 76.9, 60.6, 60.1, 21.0, 14.5, 12.4, 11.9; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −141.27 (q, J = 36.8 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.85(t, J = 35.8 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C25H29BF2N3O6 516.2127; found 516.2144.

    3-(2-Acetoxyethen-1-yl)-5-(2-formylmethyl)-1,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (8)

    The suspension of compound 7 (1.0 g, 1.93 mmol) in water (20 mL) was treated with TFA (4 mL) and heated at 110 °C for 20 min. After the mixture cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered off and dried to give 0.9 g (95%) of pure 8.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.72 (s, 1H), 8.70 (d, J = 12.7 Hz, 1H), 7.46 (s, 1H), 7.06 (d, J = 12.7 Hz, 1H), 4.42 (s, 2H), 4.39 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 4.30 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (s, 3H), 2.51 (s, 3H), 2.23 (s, 3H), 1.41–1.33 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 195.4, 167.0, 163.6, 154.4, 153.5, 147.6, 147.5, 144.8, 134.9, 133.2, 123.5, 122.0, 121.2, 104.8, 64.5, 61.0, 60.5, 43.5, 30.9, 25.3, 20.7, 14.2, 12.0; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −139.73 to −140.17 (m); 11B NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ 0.97 (t, J = 33.3 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C23H24BF2N2O7 489.1654; found 489.1667.

    3,5-Bis(2-dimethylaminoethen-1-yl)-1,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (9)

    To a hot solution of compound 7 (0.15 g, 0.29 mmol) in acetonitrile (15 mL) a methanolic solution of dimethylamine (0.04 g, 0.87 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 3 min, and the another portion of dimethylamine in methanol (0.02 g, 0.58 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was refluxed for 10 min. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered off and dried. The yield of pure 9 is 0.11 g (78%).
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.18 (d, J = 13.4 Hz, 2H), 6.85 (s, 1H), 6.20 (d, J = 13.4 Hz, 2H), 4.33–4.27 (m, 4H), 3.02 (s, 12H), 2.40 (s, 6H), 1.38 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 165.8, 154.9, 151.0, 150.8, 141.3, 133.8, 117.9, 111.6, 88.2, 59.9, 40.8, 14.5, 12.3; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −141.39 (t, J = 35.3 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.98 (t, J = 35.8 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C25H32BF2N4O4 501.2495; found 501.2518.

    3,5-Bis(2-formylmethyl)-1,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (10)

    A solution of 9 (0.035 g, 0.069 mmol) in 40% aqueous acetic acid (50 mL) was stirred at 100 °C for 20 min. Then the reaction mixture was diluted with water and extracted with CHCl3 (3 × 15 mL). Then the organic layer was washed with water (2 × 20 mL) and dried over Na2SO4. The organic layer was evaporated to dryness. The crude product was purified by silica gel column chromatography using 1:1 hexane/EtOAc as the eluent to give 0.03 g (95%) of compound 10.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.71(s, 2H), 7.59 (s, 1H), 4.41 (s, 4H), 4.29 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 4H), 2.58 (s, 6H), 1.35 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 194.9, 163.3, 155.5, 147.1, 133.8, 125.7, 121.8, 60.7, 43.5, 14.2, 12.1; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −139.74 to −140.16 (m); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 0.73 (t, J = 32.9 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C21H22BF2N2O6 447.1548; found 447.1582.

    2,8-(1-Butyl)-10,12-dimethyl-1H,9H-5,5-difluoro-5-bora-2,4a,5a,8-tetraaza-indeno[2,1-b]fluorene-1,9-dione (11)

    A solution of compound 8 (0.87 g, 1.77 mmol) in n-butylamine (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. Then the mixture was diluted with CHCl3 and washed with 2% aqueous HCl (250 mL) and with water (2 × 50 mL). Then the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated to dryness. The yield of 11 is 0.74 g (90%).
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.60 (s, 1H), 7.23 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 6.65 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 3.92 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 4H), 2.75 (s, 6H), 1.75 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 4H), 1.38 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 160.1, 153.2, 145.1, 137.6, 123.1, 120.9, 97.2, 48.3, 31.7, 20.0, 13.7, 11.5; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −145.99 (q, J = 30.0 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.03 (t, J = 31.4 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C25H28BF2N4O2 465.2283; found 465.2308.

    1,3-Bis(2-dimethylaminoethen-1-yl)-5,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacene (12)

    The mixture of compound 1 (1.96 g, 5 mmol) and DMF dimethyl acetal (3.88 g, 32.6 mmol) in toluene (150 mL) was heated at 100 °C for 24 h. Then the reaction mixture was evaporated to dryness, and the crude product was recrystallized from acetonitrile and filtered off to give 1.99 g (79%) of compound 12.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 8.28 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 7.02 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 6.77 (s, 1H), 6.21 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 5.90 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 4.32–4.29 (m, 4H), 3.10 (s, 6H), 3.01 (s, 6H), 2.77 (s, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 1.39–1.36 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 165.9, 165.8, 160.7, 154.1, 151.1, 149.4, 148.9, 136.0, 131.2 129.9, 129.0, 128.2, 116.6, 113.3, 112.6, 91.2, 88.1, 60.0, 59.3, 40.8, 14.53, 14.45, 14.1, 11.8; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ: −141.07 (q, J = 35.3 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 1.62 (t, J = 35.7 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C25H32BF2N4O4 501.2495; found 501.2488.

    1,3-Bis(2-formylmethyl)-5,7-dimethyl-2,6-dicarbethoxy-4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a,-diaza-s-indacene (13)

    The mixture of compound 12 (1.01 g, 2 mmol) and 100 mL of 25% aqueous acetic acid was heated at 55 °C for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature the precipitate was filtered off, washed with water, and dried to give 0.75 g (83%) of pure 13.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.74 (s, 1H), 9.72 (s, 1H), 7.39 (s, 1H), 4.42 (s, 2H), 4.33 (q, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 4.29 (q, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 4.04 (s, 2H), 2.82 (s, 3H), 2.53 (s, 3H), 1.38 (t, J = 6 Hz, 3H), 1.31 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 197.0, 195.5, 166.0, 163.3, 151.7, 150.2, 136.1, 135.4, 132.3, 124.5, 123.0, 120.7, 60.9, 60.7, 43.4, 40.5, 15.5, 14.3, 14.1, 12.2; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −141.74 to −142.10 (m); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 0.80 (t, J = 32.3 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C21H22BF2N2O6 447.1548, found 447.1572.

    2-Carbethoxy-7-(1-butyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-(2-dimethylaminoethen-1-yl)-4,4-difluoro-3a,4a,7-triaza-4-bora-cyclopenta[b]fluoren-8-on (14)

    To the solution of compound 12 (1.01 g, 2 mmol) in acetonitrile (80 mL) n-butylamine (0.43 g, 6 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 48 h. Then the reaction mixture was diluted with 100 mL of DCM and washed with 1% aqueous HCl and then with water. Then the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated to dryness. The residue was purified by recrystallization from CCl4. The yield of pure 14 is 0.8 g (82%).
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.64 (bs, 1H) 7.29 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 6.89 (s, 1H), 6.54 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 6.43 (bs, 1H), 4.32–4.27 (m, 4H), 3.94 (t, J = 6 Hz), 3.30 (s, 3H), 3.10 (s, 3H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.39 (s, 3H), 1.73–1.67 (m, 2H) 1.38–1.35 (m, 5H), 0.95 (t, J = 6 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 165.7, 159.0, 157.9, 149.9, 146.4, 138.8, 131.6, 131.4, 129.6, 118.8, 116.4, 109.5, 98.6, 59.3, 49.7, 46.0, 37.0, 31.6, 20.0, 14.5, 14.1, 13.7, 11.6; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −143.28 (q, J = 35.3 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 1.73 (t, J = 35.8 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C25H30BF2N4O3 483.2378; found 483.2421.

    2-Carbethoxy-7-(1-butyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-(2-butylaminoethen-1-yl)-4,4-difluoro-3a,4a,7-triaza-4-bora-cyclopenta[b]fluoren-8-on (15)

    To the solution of compound 14 (0.4 g, 0.8 mmol) in acetonitrile (15 mL) n-butylamine (0.7 g, 12 mmol) was added and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 72 h. Then the reaction mixture was diluted with DCM (100 mL) and washed with 1% aqueous HCl and then with water. Then the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated to dryness. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography using the 3:2 hexane/EtOAc mixture as the eluent to give 0.21 g (50%) of compound 15.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.65 (bs, 1H), 7.27 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 6.92 (bs, 1H), 6.53 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 4.29 (q, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 3.93 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 3.38 (bs, 2H), 2.76 (s, 3H), 2.37 (s, 3H), 1.75–1.60 (m, 4H), 1.36 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 7H), 0.97–0.93 (m, 6H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 165.1, 158.5, 153.9, 150.3, 145.8, 138.3, 132.1, 130.7, 129.1, 118.2, 116.2, 110.3, 98.1, 90.3, 58.9, 49.4, 42.4, 32.4, 31.1, 30.1, 29.2, 22.2, 19.5, 14.0, 13.6, 13.2, 11.2; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −142.89 to −143.45 (m); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.66 (t, J = 34.6 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C27H34BF2N4O3 511.2702; found 511.2734.

    2-Carbethoxy-7-(1-butyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-(2-formylmethyl)-4,4-difluoro-3a,4a,7-triaza-4-bora-cyclopenta[b]fluoren-8-on (16)

    The mixture of compound 14 (0.212 g, 0.44 mmol), acetic acid (6 mL), and water (6 mL) in methanol (10 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. Then the reaction mixture was diluted with water and extracted with CHCl3 (3 × 15 mL). The organic layer was washed with water (2 × 20 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated to dryness. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography using a 1:2 hexane/EtOAc mixture as the eluent to give 0.2 g (70%) of pure 16.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 9.87 (s, 1H), 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.15 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 6.52 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 4.65 (s, 2H), 4.32 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 3.78 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.46 (s, 3H), 1.69–1.61 (m, 2H), 1.40–1.32 (m, 5H), 0.93 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ 164.1, 159.6, 158.7, 153.2, 144.5, 142.2, 138.8, 132.2, 128.3, 121.7, 120.2, 98.9, 60.2, 53.5, 48.6, 43.2, 31.6, 29.7, 19.9, 14.8, 14.3, 13.6, 12.0; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −141.05 (q, J = 32.5 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.02 (t, J = 32.6 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C23H25BF2N3O4 456.1916; found 456.1941.

    2-Carbethoxy-7-(1-butyl)-1,3,5-trimethyl-4,4-difluoro-3a,4a,7-triaza-4-bora-cyclopenta[b]fluoren-8-on (17)

    The solution of compound 16 (0.15 g, 0.33 mmol) in ethylene glycol (15 mL) was refluxed for 1 min. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was diluted with water and extracted with CHCl3 (3 × 15 mL). The organic layer was washed with water (2 × 20 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and evaporated to dryness. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography using a 1:1 hexane/EtOAc mixture as the eluent to give 0.02 g (14%) of compound 17.
    1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 7.27 (s, 1H), 7.21 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 1H), 6.45 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 1H), 4.31 (q, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.90 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.99 (s, 3H), 2.78 (s, 3H), 2.34 (s, 3H), 1.71–1.68 (m, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 1.39 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 5H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H); 13C{1H} NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ 164.3, 161.1, 158.8, 157.7, 142.7, 142.1, 138.8, 131.3, 128.3, 120.2, 119.2, 98.5, 59.9, 48.6, 31.6, 29.7, 19.9, 14.7, 14.3, 13,7 11.9; 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −143.34 (q, J = 32.4 Hz); 11B NMR (128 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.10 (t, J = 32.4 Hz); HRMS (APCI-TOF) m/z: [M – H]− calcd for C22H25BF2N3O3 428.1967; found 428.1992.

      3
      4,4'-Difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacenes (BODIPYs) as components of novel light active materials
      Benstead, Michael; Mehl, Georg H.; Boyle, Ross W.
      Tetrahedron (2011), 67 (20), 3573-3601CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review on 4,4'-Difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacenes (BODIPYs) as components of novel light active materials. The remarkable fluorescence properties of BODIPYs give them great potential as photoactive materials. Increasing interest in the chem. of BODIPYs is helping to fuel the no. of applications for which they can be used, including non-material-based applications, such as chemosensors and as imaging agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXlsVGns7w%253D&md5=213cd9d3e376745ade1fde16cdd080df
      open URL
    4. 4
      Boens, N.; Leen, V.; Dehaen, W. Fluorescent Indicators Based on BODIPY. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41, 1130– 1172,  DOI: 10.1039/C1CS15132K
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Fluorescent indicators based on BODIPY
      Boens, Noel; Leen, Volker; Dehaen, Wim
      Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (3), 1130-1172CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. This crit. review covers the advances made using the 4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (BODIPY) scaffold as a fluorophore in the design, synthesis and application of fluorescent indicators for pH, metal ions, anions, biomols., reactive oxygen species, reactive nitrogen species, redox potential, chem. reactions and various phys. phenomena. The sections of the review describing the criteria for rational design of fluorescent indicators and the math. expressions for analyzing spectrophotometric and fluorometric titrns. are applicable to all fluorescent probes (206 refs.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xns1ygsA%253D%253D&md5=98531e55ea0e8130360135a0fa4deb59

    5. 5
      Umezawa, K.; Citterio, D.; Suzuki, K. New Trends in Near-Infrared Fluorophores for Bioimaging. Anal. Sci. 2014, 30, 327– 349,  DOI: 10.2116/analsci.30.327
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      New trends in near-infrared fluorophores for bioimaging
      Umezawa, Keitaro; Citterio, Daniel; Suzuki, Koji
      Analytical Sciences (2014), 30 (3), 327-349CODEN: ANSCEN; ISSN:0910-6340. (Japan Society for Analytical Chemistry)
      This review summarizes progress in the field of near-IR (NIR) fluorophores achieved during the last decade from the viewpoint of chem. Those compds. are of wide interest in bioanal. and bioimaging, such as in vivo fluorescence imaging. Particular focus is placed on the recent developments of BODIPY and rhodamine derivs., which belong to the most evolved NIR fluorophores. The data compiled in this review, including the chem. structures and optical properties of all compds. introduced, provide readers of this article with an overview of the field of NIR fluorophores.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXlvFCqurk%253D&md5=6851108fe95aa5e62ea3651d22323b2e
      open URL
    6. 6
      Lu, H.; Mack, J.; Yang, Y.; Shen, Z. Structural Modification Strategies for The Rational Design of Red/Nir Region BODIPYs. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2014, 43, 4778– 4823,  DOI: 10.1039/C4CS00030G
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Structural modification strategies for the rational design of red/NIR region BODIPYs
      Lu, Hua; Mack, John; Yang, Yongchao; Shen, Zhen
      Chemical Society Reviews (2014), 43 (13), 4778-4823CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This review focuses on classifying different types of long wavelength absorbing BODIPY dyes based on the wide range of structural modification methods that have been adopted, and on tabulating their spectral and photophys. properties. The structure-property relationships are analyzed in depth with ref. to mol. modeling calcns., so that the effectiveness of the different structural modification strategies for shifting the main BODIPY spectral bands to longer wavelengths can be readily compared, along with their effects on the fluorescence quantum yield (ΦF) values. This should facilitate the future rational design of red/NIR region BODIPY dyes for a wide range of different applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXpsVKis7Y%253D&md5=74c9f05ec01e641943d1a837c95899f0
      open URL
    7. 7
      Ni, Y.; Wu, J. Far-Red and Near Infrared Bodipy Dyes: Synthesis and Applications for Fluorescent pH Probes and Bio-Imaging. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2014, 12, 3774– 3791,  DOI: 10.1039/c3ob42554a
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Far-red and near infrared BODIPY dyes: synthesis and applications for fluorescent pH probes and bio-imaging
      Ni, Yong; Wu, Jishan
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2014), 12 (23), 3774-3791CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Far-red and near IR (NIR) emissive dyes have advantages in the development of fluorescent probes and labeling for bio-imaging in living systems since fluorescence in the long-wavelength region would generate min. photo-toxicity to biol. components, deep tissue penetration and minimal background from auto-fluorescence by bio-mols. BODIPY dyes are attractive due to their excellent photo-phys. properties and potential for fluorescence-based sensing and bio-imaging applications. Thus, numerous research papers have emerged to develop BODIPY-based dyes with absorption and emission in the long-wavelength spectral region (650-900 nm). This review summarizes the general strategies to obtain far-red and NIR BODIPYs. Moreover, their applications for fluorescent pH probes and imaging or labeling in living systems are highlighted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXosValsL0%253D&md5=da423d9a60835fcc2fddc112053c3503
      open URL
    8. 8
      Singh, S. P.; Gayathri, T. Evolution of Bodipy Dyes as Potential Sensitizers for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2014, 2014 (22), 4689– 4707,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201400093
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      open URL
    9. 9
      Boens, N.; Verbelen, B.; Dehaen, W. Postfunctionalization of The Bodipy Core: Synthesis and Spectroscopy. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2015, 2015 (30), 6577– 6595,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201500682
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Postfunctionalization of the BODIPY Core: Synthesis and Spectroscopy
      Boens, Noel; Verbelen, Bram; Dehaen, Wim
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2015), 2015 (30), 6577-6595CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      In this review we describe the various new methodologies for synthetic postmodification of the BODIPY core designed and developed by our research groups, as well as their electronic spectroscopic properties. We discuss the different strategies created for functionalization of the BODIPY framework at the pyrrole C-ring positions and the meso-position. Halogenated boron dipyrrins are substrates for nucleophilic substitution or Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions. α-Unsubstituted BODIPYs can be functionalized with N and C nucleophiles through oxidative or vicarious nucleophilic substitution (VNS) of the α-hydrogen atoms. Combining this methodol. with reversible Michael addn. onto nitrostyrenes provides a route to 3-styrylated BODIPYs. Furthermore, the one-step, Pd-catalyzed C-H arylation of 3,5-unsubstituted BODIPYs leads to 3- and 3,5-arylated dyes. Finally, radical C-H arylation at the 3,5-positions of α-unsubstituted BODIPYs provides an addnl. synthesis route to arylated dyes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlOhu77J&md5=9db4f014d2937b409188c06acc9335b3
      open URL
    10. 10
      Banuelos, J. BODIPY Dye, The Most Versatile Fluorophore Ever?. Chem. Rec. 2016, 16, 335– 348,  DOI: 10.1002/tcr.201500238
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      BODIPY Dye, the Most Versatile Fluorophore Ever?
      Banuelos, Jorge
      Chemical Record (2016), 16 (1), 335-348CODEN: CRHEAK; ISSN:1528-0691. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      BODIPY laser dyes constitute a fascinating topic of research in modern photochem. due to the large variety of options its chromophore offers, which is ready available for a multitude of synthetic routes. Indeed, in the literature one can find a huge battery of compds. based on the indacene core. The possibility of modulating the spectroscopic properties or inducing new photophys. processes by the substitution pattern of the BODIPY dyes has boosted the no. of scientific and technol. applications for these fluorophores. Along the following lines, I will overview the main results achieved in our lab. with BODIPYs oriented to optoelectronic as well to biophotonic applications, stressing the more relevant photophys. issues to be considered in the design of a tailor-made BODIPY for a certain application and pointing out some of the remaining challenges.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmslGrtw%253D%253D&md5=52a8451c46c239a7ceb0b5f807e0b76d
      open URL

      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      Vecchi; Galloni, P.; Floris, B.; Dudkin, S. V.; Nemykin, V. N. Metallocenes meet porphyrinoids: Consequences of a ″fusion″. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2015, 291, 95– 171,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ccr.2015.02.005
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Metallocenes meet porphyrinoids: Consequences of a "fusion"
      Vecchi, Andrea; Galloni, Pierluca; Floris, Barbara; Dudkin, Semyon V.; Nemykin, Victor N.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2015), 291 (), 95-171CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Historic as well as new developments in chem. of metallocenyl-contg. porphyrins, phthalocyanines, naphthalocyanines, tetraazaporphyrins, subphthalocyanines, subporphyrins, BODIPYs, azaBODIPYs, and related systems were overviewed. Synthetic pathways for prepn. as well as the redox and photophys. properties of metallocenyl-type compds. in which organometallic substituents connected to the resp. core π-system via (i) equatorial covalent bond; (ii) axial covalent or coordination bond; (iii) β,β'-fusion into the arom. system; and (iv) η5- or η6-bonds to the central metal ion are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjt1alu7w%253D&md5=e1dd5d788d7ffd0c349291ddfb2a563b

    13. 13
      Vecchi, A.; Galloni, P.; Floris, B.; Nemykin, V. N. New developments in chemistry of organometallic porphyrins and their analogs. J. Porphyrins Phthalocyanines 2013, 17, 165– 196,  DOI: 10.1142/S1088424613300012
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      New developments in chemistry of organometallic porphyrins and their analogs
      Vecchi, Andrea; Galloni, Pierluca; Floris, Barbara; Nemykin, Victor N.
      Journal of Porphyrins and Phthalocyanines (2013), 17 (3), 165-196CODEN: JPPHFZ; ISSN:1088-4246. (World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.)
      A review is presented on new developments in chem. of organometallic porphyrins and their analogs reported between 2007 and mid 2012. Synthetic strategies for prepn., as well as properties of metallocenyl-type compds. in which organometallic substituents connected to the porphyrinoid via (i) axial coordination; (ii) covalent bond to meso- or β-pyrrolic position; or (iii) β,β'-fused into the arom. system as well as porphyrinoids with organometallic fragments σ-bonded in η1-fashion were overviewed. Synthetic strategies for prepn., as well as properties of metallocenyl-type compds. and porphyrinoids with organometallic fragments σ-bonded in η1-fashion were overviewed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnsVOmt7s%253D&md5=4855f7b9f0a100669230a20bf668555b
      open URL
    14. 14
      Saha, S.; Agarwalla, H.; Gupta, H.; Baidya, M.; Suresh, E.; Ghosh, S. K.; Das, A. New chemodosimetric probe for the specific detection of Hg2+ in physiological condition and its utilisation for cell imaging studies. Dalton Trans. 2013, 42, 15097– 15105,  DOI: 10.1039/c3dt51744f
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      open URL
    15. 15
      Wang, E.; Qiao, H.; Zhou, Y.; Pang, L.; Yu, F.; Zhang, J.; Ma, T. A novel ″turn-on″ fluorogenic probe for sensing hypochlorous acid based on BODIPY. RSC Adv. 2015, 5, 73040– 73045,  DOI: 10.1039/C5RA14118D
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      A novel "turn-on" fluorogenic probe for sensing hypochlorous acid based on BODIPY
      Wang, Enze; Qiao, Han; Zhou, Yanmei; Pang, Lanfang; Yu, Fang; Zhang, Junli; Ma, Tongsen
      RSC Advances (2015), 5 (89), 73040-73045CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A highly selective and sensitive boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) based fluorescent probe (Bodipy-Hy) for the detection of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) was designed and easily synthesized by the condensation reaction (C=N) of BODIPY aldehyde (BODIPY-AL) and hydrazine hydrate, which contain a newer group compared with other similar probes. With the specific HOCl-promoted oxidn. grade of the C=N bond increasing, the fluorescence intensity of Bodipy-Hy gradually increased more than 11-fold. And the fluorescent quantum yield enhances from 0.06 to 0.62. A linear increase of fluorescence intensity could be obsd. under the optimum conditions with increasing HOCl concn. over a wide linear range 0-22.5 μM, then a lower detection limit of 56 nM based on 3 × δblank/k was obtained. Moreover, the probe can also be successfully applied to imaging HOCl in living cells with low cytotoxicity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlSnu7bM&md5=0426d85b6f8dcb64cb0c15e3208234b0
      open URL
    16. 16
      Stone, J.; Mack, J.; Nyokong, T.; Kimura, M.; Kobayashi, N. Photophysical properties of a novel styryl-BODIPY with a fused crown ether moiety. J. Porphyrins Phthalocyanines 2018, 22, 1– 9,  DOI: 10.1142/S1088424617500699

      Photophysical properties of a novel styryl-BODIPY with a fused crown ether moiety
      Stone, Justin; Mack, John; Nyokong, Tebello; Kimura, Mitsumi; Kobayashi, Nagao
      Journal of Porphyrins and Phthalocyanines (2018), 22 (1/3), 1-9CODEN: JPPHFZ; ISSN:1088-4246. (World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.)
      The synthesis and characterization of a crown-ether-substituted 3-styrylBODIPY dye with a 4-isopropylphenyl group at the meso-position is reported. The effect that the incorporation of Na+ ions into the crown ether moiety has on the photophys. properties is investigated.

    17. 17
      Chua, M. H.; Kim, T.; Lim, Z. L.; Gopalakrishna, T. Y.; Ni, Y.; Xu, J.; Kim, D.; Wu, J. BODIPY-Based Antiaromatic Macrocycles: Facile Synthesis by Knoevenagel Condensation and Unusual Aggregation-Enhanced Two-Photon Absorption Properties. Chem. - Eur. J. 2018, 24, 2232– 2241,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201705271
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      BODIPY-Based Antiaromatic Macrocycles: Facile Synthesis by Knoevenagel Condensation and Unusual Aggregation-Enhanced Two-Photon Absorption Properties
      Chua, Ming Hui; Kim, Taeyeon; Lim, Zheng Long; Gopalakrishna, Tullimilli Y.; Ni, Yong; Xu, Jianwei; Kim, Dongho; Wu, Jishan
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2018), 24 (9), 2232-2241CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two stable boron dipyrromethene (BODIPY)-based antiarom. macrocycles, Mc-Fur and Mc-Th, were synthesized through a 1-pot Knoevenagel condensation reaction between a BODIPY precursor and furan-2,5-dicarboxaldehyde or thiophene-2,5-dicarboxaldehyde, resp. 1H NMR spectroscopic characterization of the two macrocycles supported their highly antiarom. character. The oxidn. properties of the two macrocycles were studied through ESR spectroscopy and UV/visible absorption spectrophotometry, which suggested the formation of a stable monoradical cation species on 1st oxidn. followed by an arom. dicationic species on subsequent oxidn. Both mols. have a nearly planar π-conjugated backbone and show a strong tendency to aggregate in soln. due to efficient stacking of the antiarom. macrocycles. Transient absorption and two-photon absorption (TPA) measurements in soln. and aggregated states of the macrocycles revealed that aggregation resulted in large enhancement of TPA cross sections and increased excited-state lifetimes, in accordance with the decrease in the antiarom. character in the aggregated state.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVemtLo%253D&md5=83ac4d5819001c144d1f203e7904d020
      open URL
    18. 18
      Xiong, H.; Kos, P.; Yan, Y.; Zhou, K.; Miller, J. B.; Elkassih, S.; Siegwart, D. J. Activatable Water-Soluble Probes Enhance Tumor Imaging by Responding to Dysregulated pH and Exhibiting High Tumor-to-Liver Fluorescence Emission Contrast. Bioconjugate Chem. 2016, 27, 1737– 1744,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.bioconjchem.6b00242
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Activatable Water-Soluble Probes Enhance Tumor Imaging by Responding to Dysregulated pH and Exhibiting High Tumor-to-Liver Fluorescence Emission Contrast
      Xiong, Hu; Kos, Petra; Yan, Yunfeng; Zhou, Kejin; Miller, Jason B.; Elkassih, Sussana; Siegwart, Daniel J.
      Bioconjugate Chemistry (2016), 27 (7), 1737-1744CODEN: BCCHES; ISSN:1043-1802. (American Chemical Society)
      Dysregulated pH has been recognized as a universal tumor microenvironment signature that can delineate tumors from normal tissues. Existing fluorescent probes that activate in response to pH are hindered by either fast clearance (in the case of small mols.) or high liver background emission (in the case of large particles). There remains a need to design water-sol., long circulating, pH-responsive nanoprobes with high tumor-to-liver contrast. Herein, we report a modular chem. strategy to create acidic pH-sensitive and water-sol. fluorescent probes for high in vivo tumor detection and minimal liver activation. A combination of a modified Knoevenagel reaction and PEGylation yielded a series of NIR BODIPY fluorophores with tunable pKas, high quantum yield, and optimal orbital energies to enable photoinduced electron transfer (PeT) activation in response to pH. After i.v. administration, Probe 5c localized to tumors and provided excellent tumor-to-liver contrast (apparent T/L = 3) because it minimally activates in the liver. This phenomenon was further confirmed by direct ex vivo imaging expts. on harvested organs. Because no targeting ligands were required, we believe that this report introduces a versatile strategy to directly synthesize sol. probes with broad potential utility including fluorescence-based image-guided surgery, cancer diagnosis, and theranostic nanomedicine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsFGlu7g%253D&md5=ab1c2c8ea7362d327c34c1f8429e6b06
      open URL
    19. 19
      Zhang, X.; Xiao, Y.; Qi, J.; Qu, J.; Kim, B.; Yue, X.; Belfield, K. D. Long-Wavelength, Photostable, Two-Photon Excitable BODIPY Fluorophores Readily Modifiable for Molecular Probes. J. Org. Chem. 2013, 78, 9153– 9160,  DOI: 10.1021/jo401379g
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Long-Wavelength, Photostable, Two-Photon Excitable BODIPY Fluorophores Readily Modifiable for Molecular Probes
      Zhang, Xinfu; Xiao, Yi; Qi, Jing; Qu, Junle; Kim, Bosung; Yue, Xiling; Belfield, Kevin D.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 78 (18), 9153-9160CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Near-IR (NIR) fluorescent probes are increasingly popular in biol. imaging and sensing, as long-wavelength (650-900 nm) excitation and emission have the advantages of min. photodamage, deep tissue penetration, and min. interference from autofluorescence in living systems. Here, a series of long-wavelength BODIPY dyes SPC, DC-SPC, DPC, and DC-DPC are synthesized conveniently and efficiently. They exhibit excellent photophys. properties in far red to near-IR region, including large extinction coeffs., high fluorescence quantum yields, good photostability, and reasonable two-photon absorption cross section. Comparison of single-mol. imaging confirms that DPC is a much more efficient and more photostable NIR fluorophore than the commonly used Cy5. Also importantly, two kinds of convenient functionalization sites have been reserved: the aryl iodide for organometallic couplings and the terminal alkyne groups for click reactions. Further derivs. DC-SPC-PPh3 exhibit specificity to localize in mitochondria. The introduction of triphenylphosphonium (TPP) moieties mediates its hydrophilic-lipophilic balance and makes DC-SPC-PPh3 appropriate for cell labeling. Their long-wavelength emission at ∼650 nm can efficiently avoid the spectral crosstalk with other probes emitting in the visible light region. Superior photostability, low cytotoxicity, and two-photon excitable properties demonstrate its utility as a std. colocalizing agent to est. the other probes' local distribution.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlGnur7N&md5=8af8eca062cf9aa5182afdba0c5fc5ab
      open URL

      Zhou, X.; Yu, C.; Feng, Z.; Yu, Y.; Wang, J.; Hao, E.; Wei, Y.; Mu, X.; Jiao, L. Highly Regioselective α-Chlorination of the BODIPY Chromophore with Copper(II) Chloride. Org. Lett. 2015, 17, 4632– 4635,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.5b02383
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Highly Regioselective α-Chlorination of the BODIPY Chromophore with Copper(II) Chloride
      Zhou, Xin; Yu, Changjiang; Feng, Zeya; Yu, Yang; Wang, Jun; Hao, Erhong; Wei, Yun; Mu, Xiaolong; Jiao, Lijuan
      Organic Letters (2015), 17 (18), 4632-4635CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      A general and efficient method for α-chlorination of 4,4'-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacenes (BODIPYs) was developed using CuCl2 as chlorination reagent. The reaction is characterized by complete 3/5-positions of BODIPY regioselectivity. This unusual highly regioselective α-halogenation of BODIPY is in sharp contrast to previously reported halogenation methods which preferred to occur first at the 2,6-positions of BODIPY. This approach provides a straightforward, facile, and economical route to 3- and/or 5-chloroBODIPYs with various meso-groups (H, alkyl, and aryl) and their derivs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Regioselective 2,6-halogenation of BODIPYs in hexafluoro-2-propanol (HFIP) afforded products in less than 5 min. Halogenated BODIPYs were subjected to Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions to form novel meso-alkyl polymeric BODIPY dyes.

      Ye, Jia-Hai; Wang, Guangpu; Huang, Chengmei; Hu, Zhengjuan; Zhang, Whenchao; Zhang, Yan
      Synthesis (2012), 44 (1), 104-110CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:0039-7881. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
      Efficient and convenient methods for the mono- and dibromination of 1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-substituted BODIPYs were developed by using copper(II) bromide as the bromination reagent under mild reactions, in good to excellent yields. The selectivity of mono- or dibromination depends strongly on the additives of the reactions.

      A New Approach to the Synthesis of meso-CN-Substituted BODIPYs
      Yakubovskyi, Viktor P.; Didukh, Natalia O.; Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Kovtun, Yuriy P.
      ChemistrySelect (2016), 1 (7), 1462-1466CODEN: CHEMUD; ISSN:2365-6549. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A preparative synthetic procedure to the meso-CN substituted BODIPY has been developed. This method is based on the addn. of KCN to the borondipyrromethene moiety of the meso-unsubstituted mols. in the presence of a crown ether with further oxidn. with Pb(OAc)4. The CN group at this position causes an essential bathochromic shift in absorption/emission and influence on other physicochem. properties of borondipyrromethenes over a wide range.

      25
      Testing the Limits of the BOPHY Platform: Preparation, Characterization, and Theoretical Modeling of BOPHYs and Organometallic BOPHYs with Electron-Withdrawing Groups at β-Pyrrolic and Bridging Positions
      Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Nemez, Dion B.; Davis, Rebecca L.; Singh, Simarpreet; Herbert, David E.; King, Alex J.; Ziegler, Christopher J.; Nemykin, Victor N.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (59), 14786-14796CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Several BOPHY derivs. with and without ferrocene fragments, and with electron-withdrawing ester groups appended to the β-pyrrolic positions have been prepd. and characterized by NMR, UV/Vis near-IR (NIR), high-resoln. mass spectrometry, and fluorescence spectroscopy, as well as x-ray crystallog. The redox properties of new BOPHYs were probed by electrochem. (cyclic and differential pulse voltammetry) and spectroelectrochem. methods. In an attempt to prep. BOPHY derivs. with a cyano group at the bridging position using a similar approach for BODIPY cyanation, adducts from the nucleophilic attack of the cyanide anion on the bridging position in BOPHY have been isolated and characterized by spectroscopic methods. Oxidn. of such adducts, however, resulted in formation of either the starting BOPHYs, or partial extrusion of the BF2 fragment from the BOPHY core, which was confirmed by spectroscopy and x-ray crystallog. DFT and TDDFT calcns. on all target materials correlate well with the exptl. data, and suggest the dramatic redn. of the nitrogen atom basicity at the hydrazine bridge of the BOPHY upon introduction of the cyano group at the bridging-carbon atom.

      Zhao, N.; Vicente, M. G. H.; Fronczek, F. R.; Smith, K. M. Synthesis of 3,8-Dichloro-6-ethyl-1,2,5,7-tetramethyl-BODIPY from an Asymmetric Dipyrroketone and Reactivity Studies at the 3,5,8-Positions. Chem. - Eur. J. 2015, 21, 6181– 6192,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201406550
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      Synthesis of 3,8-Dichloro-6-ethyl-1,2,5,7-tetramethyl-BODIPY from an Asymmetric Dipyrroketone and Reactivity Studies at the 3,5,8-Positions
      Zhao, Ning; Vicente, M. Graca H.; Fronczek, Frank R.; Smith, Kevin M.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (16), 6181-6192CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The asym. BODIPY 1 a (BODIPY=4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene), contg. two chloro substituents at the 3,8-positions and a reactive 5-Me group, was synthesized from the asym. dipyrroketone 3, which was readily obtained from available pyrrole 2 a. The reactivity of 3,8-dichloro-6-ethyl-1,2,5,7-tetramethyl-BODIPY 1 a was studied by using four types of reactions. This versatile BODIPY undergoes regioselective Pd0-catalyzed Stille coupling reactions and/or regioselective nucleophilic addn./elimination reactions, first at the 8-chloro and then at the 3-chloro group, using a variety of organostannanes and N-, O-, and S-centered nucleophiles. The more reactive 5-Me group undergoes regioselective Knoevenagel condensation with an aryl aldehyde to produce a monostyryl-BODIPY, and oxidn. with 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) gives the corresponding 5-formyl-BODIPY. Study of the reactivity of asym. BODIPY 1 a led to the prepn. of a variety of functionalized BODIPYs with λmax of absorption and emission in the ranges 487-587 and 521-617 nm, resp. The longest absorbing/emitting compd. was the monostyryl-BODIPY 16, and the largest Stokes shift (49 nm) and fluorescence quantum yield (0.94) were measured for 5-thienyl-8-phenoxy-BODIPY 15. The structural properties (including 16 x-ray structures) of the new series of BODIPYs were studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXkvF2lsbs%253D&md5=09ac71addfa4e4b68966a913bee56ad7
