        Diferrocene-contg. meso-cyano-BODIPY I (4) was prepd. by the direct cyanation/oxidn. reaction of a sym. BODIPY followed by Knoevenagel condensation with ferrocenecarboxaldehyde. Ferrocene-contg. BODIPY 4 was characterized by a variety of spectroscopic, electrochem., and theor. methods, and its UV-visible-NIR spectrum has a striking similarity with a UV-visible-NIR spectrum of the previously reported magnesium 2(3),7(8),12(13),17(18)-tetracyano-3(2),8(7),13(12),18(17)-tetraferrocenyl-5,10,15,20-tetraazaporphyrin.

        Testing the Limits of the BOPHY Platform: Preparation, Characterization, and Theoretical Modeling of BOPHYs and Organometallic BOPHYs with Electron-Withdrawing Groups at β-Pyrrolic and Bridging Positions
        Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Nemez, Dion B.; Davis, Rebecca L.; Singh, Simarpreet; Herbert, David E.; King, Alex J.; Ziegler, Christopher J.; Nemykin, Victor N.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (59), 14786-14796CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Several BOPHY derivs. with and without ferrocene fragments, and with electron-withdrawing ester groups appended to the β-pyrrolic positions have been prepd. and characterized by NMR, UV/Vis near-IR (NIR), high-resoln. mass spectrometry, and fluorescence spectroscopy, as well as x-ray crystallog. The redox properties of new BOPHYs were probed by electrochem. (cyclic and differential pulse voltammetry) and spectroelectrochem. methods. In an attempt to prep. BOPHY derivs. with a cyano group at the bridging position using a similar approach for BODIPY cyanation, adducts from the nucleophilic attack of the cyanide anion on the bridging position in BOPHY have been isolated and characterized by spectroscopic methods. Oxidn. of such adducts, however, resulted in formation of either the starting BOPHYs, or partial extrusion of the BF2 fragment from the BOPHY core, which was confirmed by spectroscopy and x-ray crystallog. DFT and TDDFT calcns. on all target materials correlate well with the exptl. data, and suggest the dramatic redn. of the nitrogen atom basicity at the hydrazine bridge of the BOPHY upon introduction of the cyano group at the bridging-carbon atom.

        Synthesis of 3,8-Dichloro-6-ethyl-1,2,5,7-tetramethyl-BODIPY from an Asymmetric Dipyrroketone and Reactivity Studies at the 3,5,8-Positions
        Zhao, Ning; Vicente, M. Graca H.; Fronczek, Frank R.; Smith, Kevin M.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (16), 6181-6192CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The asym. BODIPY 1 a (BODIPY=4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene), contg. two chloro substituents at the 3,8-positions and a reactive 5-Me group, was synthesized from the asym. dipyrroketone 3, which was readily obtained from available pyrrole 2 a. The reactivity of 3,8-dichloro-6-ethyl-1,2,5,7-tetramethyl-BODIPY 1 a was studied by using four types of reactions. This versatile BODIPY undergoes regioselective Pd0-catalyzed Stille coupling reactions and/or regioselective nucleophilic addn./elimination reactions, first at the 8-chloro and then at the 3-chloro group, using a variety of organostannanes and N-, O-, and S-centered nucleophiles. The more reactive 5-Me group undergoes regioselective Knoevenagel condensation with an aryl aldehyde to produce a monostyryl-BODIPY, and oxidn. with 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) gives the corresponding 5-formyl-BODIPY. Study of the reactivity of asym. BODIPY 1 a led to the prepn. of a variety of functionalized BODIPYs with λmax of absorption and emission in the ranges 487-587 and 521-617 nm, resp. The longest absorbing/emitting compd. was the monostyryl-BODIPY 16, and the largest Stokes shift (49 nm) and fluorescence quantum yield (0.94) were measured for 5-thienyl-8-phenoxy-BODIPY 15. The structural properties (including 16 x-ray structures) of the new series of BODIPYs were studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXkvF2lsbs%253D&md5=09ac71addfa4e4b68966a913bee56ad7

        Ortiz, M. J.; Garcia-Moreno, I.; Agarrabeitia, A. R.; Duran-Sampedro, G.; Costela, A.; Sastre, R.; Lopez Arbeloa, F.; Banuelos Prieto, J.; Lopez Arbeloa, I.         29
        Red-edge-wavelength finely-tunable laser action from new BODIPY dyes
        Ortiz, M. J.; Garcia-Moreno, I.; Agarrabeitia, A. R.; Duran-Sampedro, G.; Costela, A.; Sastre, R.; Lopez Arbeloa, F.; Banuelos Prieto, J.; Lopez Arbeloa, I.
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2010), 12 (28), 7804-7811CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        New BODIPY dyes with 2 4-formylphenyl, 4-(2,2-dimethoxycarbonylvinyl)phenyl and 4-(2,2-dicyanovinyl)phenyl groups at the 3- and 5-positions were successfully designed and synthesized via Pd-catalyzed coupling reaction or Knoevenagel-type condensations. Structural modification of the BODIPY core via conjugation-extending residues significantly affects the spectroscopy and photophys. properties of the BODIPY fluorophore. These substituents cause the largest bathochromic shift in both absorption and emission spectra, which are shifted toward the red compared to its 4-Ph-substituted analog. The fluorescence quantum yields and the Stokes shifts are significantly higher than the corresponding phenyl-substituted dye. New BODIPY dyes have a high laser photostability, superior to that of com. dyes with laser emission in the same spectral region, such as Perylene Red and Rhodamine 640. The substitution introduced in these derivs. allows to obtain tunable laser emission with a bandwidth of 0.15 cm-1 and a tuning range of ≤50 nm. So with these 3 dyes it is possible to cover the spectral range 590-680 nm in a continuous way and with stable laser emission and small linewidth.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXosFaqs74%253D&md5=a01c15510d93f35224d50998f5b50447
        open URL

        Hayashi, Y.; Yamaguchi, S.; Cha, W. Y.; Kim, D.; Shinokubo, H. Synthesis of directly connected BODIPY oligomers through Suzuki-Miyaura coupling. Org. Lett. 2011, 13, 2992– 2995,  DOI: 10.1021/ol200799u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Synthesis of directly connected BODIPY oligomers through Suzuki-Miyaura coupling
        Hayashi, Yosuke; Yamaguchi, Shigeru; Cha, Won Young; Kim, Dongho; Shinokubo, Hiroshi
        Organic Letters (2011), 13 (12), 2992-2995CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        Completely conjugated β-linked BODIPY dimer and trimer, β,β'-diaryl-substituted BODIPY chromophores were prepd. by regioselective bromination/Suzuki-Miyaura coupling; the compds. exhibit bathochromic shifts in their UV-vis. and fluorescence spectra, as the conjugation extends. Treatment of a meso-arylboron dipyrrin I (1, n = 1, X1 = X2 = H, BODIPY) with NBS provides mono- and dibrominated BODIPY (2, 3, shown as I, n = 1; 2, X1 = H, X2 = Br, 3, X1 = X2 = Br) at the 2- and 6-positions in excellent yields with high regioselectivity. Borylation of 2 gave the corresponding boronic deriv. (5, X1 = H, X2 = Bpin), homocoupling of 5 with 2 and cross-coupling with 3 gave the oligomers I (4, n = 2, X1 = X2 = H; 6, n = 3, X1 = X2 = H). Arylation of 2 and 3 by coupling with 4-RC6H4B(OH)2 gave the compds. II (7, R1 = R2 = NO2, 8, R1 = R2 = NMe2, 11, R1 = NMe2, R2 = NO2). Crystal structure of 4 and 11 was detd.; the compds. feature coplanar conformation of all pyrrole and arene rings. Compds. 8 and 11 feature complete quenching of the fluorescence due to strong intramol. charge transfer from donating dimethylamino substituent.

        Efficient synthesis of panchromatic dyes for energy concentration
        Bura, Thomas; Retailleau, Pascal; Ziessel, Raymond
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (37), 6659-6663, S6659/1-S6659/10CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Covalently linked cyanine dyes are prepd. in an iterative fashion, whereby each cycle provides an addnl. module capable of energy transfer. The strategy involves substitution at the B atom of a Bodipy dye with a Grignard reagent, formylation of a phenyliodo group, and a Knoevenagel reaction between Me groups of another Bodipy unit and the formyl group, thus providing both divinyl and monovinyl derivs. suitable for use in another sequence of reactions.

        The synthesis and characterization of a family of 2-substituted BODIPY dyes are reported herein. The dyes have been prepd. using nucleophilic addn. reactions (Wittig reactions, imine, Knoevenagel & aldol condensations) which are typically more challenging for BODIPY ring systems. Structure-property relationships have also been delineated by evaluating the physicochem. properties including; absorption & emission spectroscopy, electrochem. studies (CV, DPV) and theor. calcns. (TD-DFT).

        Maligaspe, E.; Pundsack, T. J.; Albert, L. M.; Zatsikha, Y. V.; Solntsev, P. V.; Blank, D. A.; Nemykin, V. N.         [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Synthesis and Charge-Transfer Dynamics in a Ferrocene-Containing Organoboryl aza-BODIPY Donor-Acceptor Triad with Boron as the Hub
        Maligaspe, Eranda; Pundsack, Tom J.; Albert, Lauren M.; Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Solntsev, Pavlo V.; Blank, David A.; Nemykin, Victor N.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (8), 4167-4174CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A N,N'-bis(ferroceneacetylene)boryl complex of 3,3'-diphenylazadiisoindolylmethene was synthesized by the reaction of an N,N'-difluoroboryl complex of 3,3'-diphenylazadiisoindolylmethene and ferroceneacetylene magnesium bromide. The novel diiron complex was characterized by a variety of spectroscopic techniques, electrochem., and ultrafast time-resolved methods. Spectroscopy and redox behavior was correlated with the d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT calcns. An unexpected degree of coupling between the two Fc ligands was obsd. Despite a lack of conjugation between the donor and acceptor, the complex undergoes very rapid (τ = 1.7 ± 0.1 ps) photoinduced intramol. charge sepn. followed by subpicosecond charge recombination to form a triplet state with a lifetime of 4.8 ± 0.1 μs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlsFejsb4%253D&md5=0835577012525f898b6e74e84e46c594
        open URL
      34. 34
        Jiao, L.; Yu, C.; Liu, M.; Wu, Y.; Cong, K.; Meng, T.; Wang, Y.; Hao, E. Synthesis and Functionalization of Asymmetrical Benzo-Fused BODIPY Dyes. J. Org. Chem. 2010, 75, 6035– 6038,  DOI: 10.1021/jo101164a

        34
        Synthesis and Functionalization of Asymmetrical Benzo-Fused BODIPY Dyes
        Jiao, Lijuan; Yu, Changjiang; Liu, Mingming; Wu, Yangchun; Cong, Kebing; Meng, Ting; Wang, Yuqing; Hao, Erhong
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2010), 75 (17), 6035-6038CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of asym. benzo-fused BODIPY dyes were synthesized from the Sonogashira coupling and nucleophilic substitution reactions on the 3-halogenated benzo-fused BODIPY, generated from readily available 3-halogeno-1-formylisoindoles in a two-step synthetic procedure. This novel BODIPY platform provides an easy path for the linking of BODIPY fluorophore to various desired functionalities as demonstrated in this work. Most of the resulting BODIPY dyes show long-wavelength absorption and fluorescence emission, with good fluorescence quantum yields and long fluorescence lifetimes.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Naphtho[b]-fused BODIPYs: one pot Suzuki-Miyaura-Knoevenagel synthesis and photophysical properties
        Zhou, Zhikuan; Zhou, Jianping; Gai, Lizhi; Yuan, Aihua; Shen, Zhen
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2017), 53 (49), 6621-6624CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Naphtho[b]-fused BODIPYs have been facilely synthesized via Suzuki-Miyaura-Knoevenagel reaction between mono-iodo-BODIPY or 2,6-diiodo-BODIPY with (2-formylphenyl)boronic acid. This one-pot reaction represents a very straightforward approach for tuning the absorption and emission of BODIPYs in the red visible/NIR range.

      37. 37
        Wakamiya, A.; Hayashi, J.; Obata, N.; Tamaru, M.; Yamaguchi, S.; Matsuo, Y.; Saeki, A.; Seki, S.; Murakami, T.; Yamaguchi, S. Benzene-Fused BODIPY and Fully-Fused BODIPY Dimer: Impacts of The Ring-Fusing at The B Bond in The BODIPY Skeleton. Chem. Sci. 2013, 4, 1002– 1007,  DOI: 10.1039/C2SC21768F
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Benzene-fused BODIPY and fully-fused BODIPY dimer: impacts of the ring-fusing at the b bond in the BODIPY skeleton
        Wakamiya, Atsushi; Murakami, Takanori; Yamaguchi, Shigehiro
        Chemical Science (2013), 4 (3), 1002-1007CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        4,4-Difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacenes (BODIPYs) are dyes with great potentials for various applications. To establish the design principle for the modification of the BODIPY skeleton, we now investigate the electronic impacts of the introduction of ring-fused structures. DFT calcns. revealed that while the benzene-fusing at the a bond in the BODIPY skeleton increases the HOMO level, the benzene-fusing at the b bond leads to a decreased LUMO level. Based on these results, a benzo[b]-fused BODIPY (A) and a fully-fused BODIPY dimer (B) were synthesized. X-ray crystal structure anal. demonstrated that the benzo[b]-fused structure significantly perturbs the π-conjugation with enhancement of an electron-accepting azafulvene character. In the ring-fused BODIPY dimer B, the central benzene ring is largely deviated from the arom. benzene geometry. As a consequence, B has a significantly low-lying LUMO delocalized along the periphery. In cyclic voltammograms, the benzene-fused BODIPY A and fully-fused dimer B indeed showed reversible redn. waves at much less neg. potentials (E1/2 = -1.05 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 1, -0.85 V for 2), relative to a non-fused BODIPY (E1/2 = -1.40 V). In addn., the benzene-fused BODIPYs showed broad and intense absorption bands in the Vis-NIR region. In particular, the BODIPY dimer B showed an intense absorption at 629 nm with a broad shoulder band reaching 900 nm. Corresponding to the red-shifted absorption, compds. A and B showed weak fluorescence in the deep red region (λem = 690 nm, ΦF < 0.01) and in the near-IR region (940 nm, ΦF < 0.01), resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFKjs7w%253D&md5=419eb9659a72efd70c6b5890c4c5ec53
        open URL

      39. 39
        Umezawa, K.; Matsui, A.; Nakamura, Y.; Citterio, D.; Suzuki, K. Bright, Color-Tunable Fluorescent Dyes in The Vis/Nir Region: Establishment of New “Tailor-Made” Multicolor Fluorophores Based On Borondipyrromethene. Chem. - Eur. J. 2009, 15, 1096– 1106,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200801906
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Bright, color-tunable fluorescent dyes in the Vis/NIR region: establishment of new "tailor-made" multicolor fluorophores based on borondipyrromethene
        Umezawa, Keitaro; Matsui, Akihiro; Nakamura, Yuki; Citterio, Daniel; Suzuki, Koji
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2009), 15 (5), 1096-1106CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new series of high-performance fluorophores named Keio Fluors (KFL), which are based on borondipyrromethene (BODIPY), are reported. The KFL dyes cover a wide spectral range from the yellow (547 nm) to the near-IR (NIR, 738 nm) region, and their emission wavelength could be easily and subtly controlled based on simple mol. modifications only, without losing their optical properties. This "tailor-made" synthetic strategy for tuning the emission wavelength enabled the creation of fourteen KFL dyes with well-controlled emission colors (yellow, orange, red, far-red, and NIR). Moreover, these KFL dyes also retain their excellent optical properties, such as spectral bands sharper than quantum dots, high extinction coeffs. (140,000-316,000m-1cm-1), and high quantum yields (0.56-0.98), without any crit. solvent polarity dependent decrease of their brightness. These advantageous characteristics make the KFL dyes potentially useful as new candidates of fluorescent std. dyes to replace or complement existing long-wavelength fluorescent dyes, such as cyanines, oxazines, rhodamines, or other BODIPY dyes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhslCksr8%253D&md5=2d08b5419bc76ea7337dc88c4631dff8
        open URL

        Thienopyrrole-expanded BODIPY as a potential NIR photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy
        Yang, Yongchao; Guo, Qiuli; Chen, Huachao; Zhou, Zhikuan; Guo, Zijian; Shen, Zhen
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (38), 3940-3942CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The synthesis and characterization of a highly photostable bromo-substituted BODIPY dye (I) fused-ring-expanded with thienopyrrole moieties is reported. The results of MTT assays and flow cytometric analyses in living HeLa cells demonstrate that I has a high singlet oxygen quantum yield (ΦΔ = 0.63) and exhibits photocytotoxicity upon irradn. in the NIR region making it potentially suitable for use in PDT.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42
        Singlet Oxygen Generation by Novel NIR BODIPY Dyes
        Awuah, Samuel G.; Polreis, Jason; Biradar, Vidya; You, Youngjae
        Organic Letters (2011), 13 (15), 3884-3887CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        Five novel near-IR BODIPY dyes were prepd. for improved singlet oxygen generation using thiophene and bromine. Theor., optical, photostable, and singlet oxygen generation characteristics of these dyes were assessed. Predicted excitation energies by TDDFT calcns. were in good agreement (ΔE ≈ 0.06 eV) with exptl. data. All five dyes showed both excitation and emission in the NIR range. In particular, two dyes having sulfur and bromine atoms showed efficient singlet oxygen generation with high photostability.

      43. 43
        Awuah, S. G.; Das, S. K.; D’Souza, F.; You, Y.; Awuah, S. G. Thieno–Pyrrole-Fused BODIPY Intermediate as a Platform to Multifunctional NIR Agents. Chem. - Asian J. 2013, 8, 3123– 3132,  DOI: 10.1002/asia.201300855
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43
        Thieno-Pyrrole-Fused BODIPY Intermediate as a Platform to Multifunctional NIR Agents
        Awuah, Samuel G.; Das, Sushanta K.; D'Souza, Francis; You, Youngjae
        Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2013), 8 (12), 3123-3132CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The authors report the synthesis, photophys. and electrochem. properties, and in vivo fluorescence imaging of a series of new thieno-pyrrole-fused near-IR (NIR) BODIPY agents by using a versatile intermediate as a building block. The versatile thieno-pyrrole-fused BODIPY intermediate was rationally designed to bear bromo-substituents and absorb in the mid-red region (635 nm) to act as an org. electrophile for the development of NIR multifunctional agents. The use of subsequent palladium-catalyzed and nucleophilic substitution reactions afforded highly conjugated NIR BODIPYs. The novel BODIPYs exhibit long-wavelength absorptions in the NIR region (650-840 nm). The agents produce sharp fluorescence bands, and most of them display respectable quantum yields of fluorescence (0.05-0.87) useful for biomedical imaging, as demonstrated by in vivo imaging with SBDPiR740. A no. of agents in the series that are non-halogenated were reactive to O2 at the triplet photoexcited state coupled with a favorable redox potential and decent fluorescence, and hence could be potential candidates for use as photosensitizers in fluorescence-guided photodynamic therapy. Furthermore, the synthetic approach allows further functionalization of the highly conjugated NIR BODIPYs to tune the excited states (PET, ICT) and to conjugate targeting moieties for enhanced biol. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlCgtbrJ&md5=c3686b35d64d97cf22f6cc9fd8d45bd8

        Yang, S. K.; Shi, X.; Park, S.; Ha, T.; Zimmerman, S. C. A Dendritic Single-Molecule Fluorescent Probe That Is Monovalent, Photostable and Minimally Blinking. Nat. Chem. 2013, 5, 692,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.1706
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        A dendritic single-molecule fluorescent probe that is monovalent, photostable and minimally blinking
        Yang, Si Kyung; Shi, Xinghua; Park, Seongjin; Ha, Taekjip; Zimmerman, Steven C.
        Nature Chemistry (2013), 5 (8), 692-697CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Single-mol. fluorescence techniques have emerged as a powerful approach to understanding complex biol. systems. However, a challenge researchers still face is the limited photostability of nearly all org. fluorophores, including the cyanine and Alexa dyes. We report a new, monovalent probe that emits in the far-red region of the visible spectrum with properties desirable for single-mol. optical imaging. This probe is based on a ring-fused boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) core that is conjugated to a polyglycerol dendrimer (PGD). The dendrimer makes the hydrophobic fluorophore water-sol. This probe exhibits excellent brightness, with an emission max. of 705 nm. We have obsd. strikingly long and stable emission from individual PGD-BODIPY probes, even in the absence of anti-fading agents such as Trolox, a combined oxidizing-reducing agent often used in single-mol. studies for improving the photostability of common imaging probes. These interesting properties greatly simplify use of the fluorophore.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Development of non-symmetric thiophene-fused BODIPYs
        Jiang, Xin-Dong; Zhang, Houjun; Zhang, Yuanlin; Zhao, Weili
        Tetrahedron (2012), 68 (47), 9795-9801CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A series of non-sym. BODIPYs contg. thieno[3,2-b]pyrrole moiety were synthesized in 21-63% yields. The absorption and emission maxima covered from the visible green to red region. X-ray anal. indicated that the S-C bond lengths were shorter than those of thienopyrrole and thienohelicene by 0.03-0.05 Å. The crystal packing pattern suggested that strong π-π interaction, intermol. C-H···F interaction, and weak S···π interaction existed. The tunable emission was achieved by structure modifications. Oxidn. of BODIPY (λem=547 nm) with m-CPBA generated thiophene-1,1-dioxide derived BODIPY (λem=528 nm). Knoevenagel-type condensation of BODIPY with N,N-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde led to BODIPY (λem=693 nm) with extended conjugation.

        Synthetic Strategy for Low-Band Gap Oligomers and Homopolymers Using Characteristics of Thiophene-Fused Boron Dipyrromethene
        Yoshii, Ryousuke; Yamane, Honami; Tanaka, Kazuo; Chujo, Yoshiki
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 47 (11), 3755-3760CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        In this article, we demonstrate the strategy for receiving low-band gap conjugated polymers based on thiophene-fused boron dipyrromethene (TB) with homopolymer structure. A series of TB-based polymers and oligomers with low band gaps were synthesized by oxidn. coupling. The obtained polymers and their oligomers exhibited strong absorption in the range from visible to near-IR region around 400-2000 nm (ε = 168 000-26 000 M-1 cm-1) originated from efficient expansion of main-chain conjugations. From the results of cyclic voltammetry, the TB derivs. have low-lying HOMOs and LUMOs. Furthermore, the TB derivs. showed high stability in atm.

        α-Fused Dithienyl BODIPYs Synthesized by Oxidative Ring Closure
        Heyer, Elodie; Retailleau, Pascal; Ziessel, Raymond
        Organic Letters (2014), 16 (9), 2330-2333CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        Both sym. and unsym. α-fused dithienyl-BODIPY dyes were prepd. by oxidative ring closure induced by anhyd. FeCl3. Extension of the π-system in the fused BODIPY leads to a progressive shift to 579 and 665 nm resp. for the absorption wavelength maxima of the mono- and difused dyes relative to the unfused species (λabs = 502 nm). Linking such dyes to an NIR emitting module provides a panchromatic chromophore with a large absorption cross section in the visible range assocd. with efficient intramol. cascade energy transfer.

        Watley, R. L.; Awuah, S. G.; Bio, M.; Cantu, R.; Gobeze, H. B.; Nesterov, V. N.; Das, S. K.; D’Souza, F.; You, Y. Dual Functioning Thieno-Pyrrole Fused BODIPY Dyes for NIR Optical Imaging and Photodynamic Therapy: Singlet Oxygen Generation without Heavy Halogen Atom Assistance. Chem. - Asian J. 2015, 10, 1335– 1343,  DOI: 10.1002/asia.201500140
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        Dual Functioning Thieno-Pyrrole Fused BODIPY Dyes for NIR Optical Imaging and Photodynamic Therapy: Singlet Oxygen Generation without Heavy Halogen Atom Assistance
        Watley, Ryan L.; Awuah, Samuel G.; Bio, Moses; Cantu, Robert; Gobeze, Habtom B.; Nesterov, Vladimir N.; Das, Sushanta K.; D'Souza, Francis; You, Youngjae
        Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2015), 10 (6), 1335-1343CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        We discovered a rare phenomenon wherein a thieno-pyrrole fused BODIPY dye (SBDPiR690) generates singlet oxygen without heavy halogen atom substituents. SBDPiR690 generates both singlet oxygen and fluorescence. To our knowledge, this is the first example of such a finding. To establish a structure-photophys. property relationship, we prepd. SBDPiR analogs with electron-withdrawing groups at the para-position of the Ph groups. The electron-withdrawing groups increased the HOMO-LUMO energy gap and singlet oxygen generation. Among the analogs, SBDPiR688, a CF3 analog, had an excellent dual functionality of brightness (82290 M-1 cm-1) and phototoxic power (99170 M-1 cm-1) comparable to those of Pc 4, due to a high extinction coeff. (211 000 M-1 cm-1) and balanced decay (Φflu=0.39 and ΦΔ=0.47). The dual functionality of the lead compd. SBDPiR690 was successfully applied to preclin. optical imaging and for PDT to effectively control a s.c. tumor.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXntVWrtL8%253D&md5=87f0c06ae4b07d2fc87235b00c94ea7b
        open URL

        Ji, S.; Ge, J.; Escudero, D.; Wang, Z.; Zhao, J.; Jacquemin, D. Molecular Structure–Intersystem Crossing Relationship of Heavy-Atom-Free BODIPY Triplet Photosensitizers. J. Org. Chem. 2015, 80, 5958– 5963,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.5b00691
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Molecular Structure-Intersystem Crossing Relationship of Heavy-Atom-Free BODIPY Triplet Photosensitizers
        Ji, Shaomin; Ge, Jie; Escudero, Daniel; Wang, Zhijia; Zhao, Jianzhang; Jacquemin, Denis
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2015), 80 (11), 5958-5963CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A thiophene-fused BODIPY chromophore displays a large triplet-state quantum yield (ΦT = 63.7%). In contrast, when the two thienyl moieties are not fused into the BODIPY core, intersystem crossing (ISC) becomes inefficient and ΦT remains low (ΦT = 6.1%). First-principles calcns. including spin-orbit coupling (SOC) were performed to quantify the ISC. We found larger SOC and smaller singlet-triplet energy gaps for the thiophene-fused BODIPY deriv. Our results are useful for studies of the photochem. of org. chromophores.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXnvV2mtbY%253D&md5=d043c26cd3e7f6780a398642f08be59e

        Pyridone fused boron-dipyrromethenes: synthesis and properties
        Zhao, Chunchang; Zhang, Jinxin; Wang, Xuzhe; Zhang, Yanfen
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2013), 11 (2), 372-377CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A general procedure for the introduction of a pyridone moiety was developed by post-modification of the ready-made BODIPY core using a Friedlaender reaction. Three pyridone-fused BODIPYs were generated. This method is complementary to the classical method for obtaining arom. ring-fused BODIPYs, which begins with the condensation of the corresponding arom. ring-fused pyrroles. These pyridone-fused BODIPYs are distinctive, possessing favorable photophys. characteristics with strong absorption, high bright orange fluorescence and easy redn. due to the electron-withdrawing effect of the fused pyridone moiety. More important, these BODIPYs bear reactive functions which are applicable in protein labeling by bioorthogonal chem. reactions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvVSksbvK&md5=0e1ad22c2fd82cdb8faf7b1d0e0d517f
        open URL

        Highly Efficient Deep-Red- to Near-Infrared-Absorbing and Emissive Benzo/Naphtho[b]furan-Fused Boron Dipyrromethene (BODIPY)
        Li, Yue; Qiao, Zhi; Li, Tian-yi; Zeika, Olaf; Leo, Karl
        ChemPhotoChem (2018), 2 (12), 1017-1021CODEN: CHEMYH ISSN:. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two aryl-fused BODIPY dyes BF-BDP and NF-BDP were synthesized with benzofuran and naphtho[b]furan fusions on the α,β-positions of the BODIPY skeleton, resp., resulting in large linear conjugated structures. Both mols. were planar and were characterized as intense deep-red/NIR emitters with emission bands tunable by the soln. concn. Their emission bands were red-shifted to λ=730 and 760 nm in vacuum-deposited films.

        57
        An efficient method of chemical modification of BODIPY core
        Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Yakubovskyi, Viktor P.; Shandura, Mykola P.; Dubey, Igor Ya; Kovtun, Yuriy P.
        Tetrahedron (2013), 69 (10), 2233-2238CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A simple approach to the modification of BODIPY nucleus was developed. The method is based on the reaction of acetaldehyde-substituted dye with primary amines followed by cyclization of enamine intermediates. This procedure allowed prepg. a series of new BODIPY derivs. with functional substituents useful for various practical purposes, including bioconjugation and other biomedical applications. The synthesized BODIPYs annealed to a pyridone fragment are stable compds. and intense fluorophores with emission max. around 615 nm. This λem may be red-shifted by the introduction of styryl substituent.

        A simple approach to the modification of BODIPY nucleus has been developed. The method is based on the reaction of monofunctionalized acetaldehyde-substituted dye with primary amines or anilines followed by cyclization of enamine intermediates. This procedure allowed prepg. a series of new stable intensive long-wavelength BODIPY derivs. (λem = 680-720 nm) with two functional substituents useful for various practical purposes, including bioconjugation and other biomedical applications.

Tuning Electronic Structure, Redox, And Photophysical Properties in Asymmetric NIR-Absorbing Organometallic BODIPYs. Inorg. Chem. 2015, 54, 7915– 7928,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b00992
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        Tuning Electronic Structure, Redox, and Photophysical Properties in Asymmetric NIR-Absorbing Organometallic BODIPYs
        Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Maligaspe, Eranda; Purchel, Anatolii A.; Didukh, Natalia O.; Wang, Yefeng; Kovtun, Yuriy P.; Blank, David A.; Nemykin, Victor N.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2015), 54 (16), 7915-7928CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Stepwise modification of the Me groups at the α positions of BODIPY 1 was used for prepn. of a series of mono- (2, 4, and 6) and diferrocene (3) substituted donor-acceptor dyads in which the organometallic substituents are fully conjugated with the BODIPY π system. All donor-acceptor complexes have strong absorption in the NIR region and quenched steady-state fluorescence, which can be partially restored upon oxidn. of organometallic group(s). X-ray crystallog. of complexes 2-4 and 6 confirms the nearly coplanar arrangement of the ferrocene groups and the BODIPY π system. Redox properties of the target systems were studied using cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV). It was found that the first oxidn. process in all dyads is ferrocene centered, while the sepn. between the first and the second ferrocene-centered oxidn. potentials in diferrocenyl-contg. dyad 3 is ∼150 mV. The d. functional theory-polarized continuum model (DFT-PCM) and time-dependent (TD) DFT-PCM methods were used to investigate the electronic structure as well as explain the UV-vis and redox properties of organometallic compds. 2-4 and 6. TDDFT calcns. allow for assignment of the charge-transfer and π → π* transitions in the target compds. The excited state dynamics of the parent BODIPY 1 and dyads 2-4 and 6 were investigated using time-resolved transient spectroscopy. In all organometallic dyads 2-4 and 6 the initially excited state is rapidly quenched by electron transfer from the ferrocene ligand. The lifetime of the charge-sepd. state was found to be between 136 and 260 ps and demonstrates a systematic dependence on the electronic structure and geometry of BODIPYs 2-4 and 6.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1GnurfL&md5=43574dae75e2df271fdecd444849b35d
        open URL

        Zatsikha, Y. V.; Didukh, N. O.; Blesener, T.; Kayser, M. P.; Kovtun, Y. P.; Blank, D. A.; Nemykin, V. N.         Preparation, Characterization, Redox, and Photoinduced Electron-Transfer Properties of the NIR-Absorbing N-Ferrocenyl-2-Pyridone BODIPYs
        Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Didukh, Natalia O.; Blesener, Tanner; Kayser, Mathew P.; Kovtun, Yuriy P.; Blank, David A.; Nemykin, Victor N.
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2017), 2017 (2), 318-324CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Mono- and di-(N-ferrocenyl-2-pyridone)-contg. BODIPYs were prepd. using a set of ferrocene-enamine cyclization reactions. The target compds. were characterized by UV-Vis, NMR, and mass spectrometry, while their redox properties were probed by the electrochem., spectroelectrochem., and chem. oxidn. methods. Redox properties of the di(ferrocenyl)-contg. BODIPY suggestive of lack of the electronic coupling between two ferrocene groups. Oxidn. of the ferrocene(s) in the target BODIPYs results in their observable fluorescence, while transient absorption spectroscopy data indicative of the fast electron-transfer from ferrocene donor to the photoexcited BODIPY acceptor. D. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) methods were used to elucidate electronic structures of the organometallic BODIPYs and confirm the presence of the low-energy metal-to-ligand charge-transfer states in the NIR region.

        Boradipyrromethenecyanines on the base of a BODIPY nucleus annelated with a pyridone ring: a new approach to long-wavelength dual fluorescent probe design

        A no. of polymethine dyes based on a BODIPY nucleus annelated with a pyridone ring have been synthesized. The merocyanines of this series are long-wavelength and intensive dyes. Obtained for the first time, asym. anionic boradipyrromethenecyanines are also interesting from another viewpoint. These compds. are able to exist in several equil. forms which belong to polymethine or boradipyrromethene chromophoric systems. This results in the appearance of multicomponent bands in absorption and fluorescence spectra that may be used in the design of dual fluorescent probes.

        Facile Synthesis of Biphenyl-Fused BODIPY and Its Property
        Hayashi, Yosuke; Obata, Naoki; Tamaru, Masatomo; Yamaguchi, Shigeru; Matsuo, Yutaka; Saeki, Akinori; Seki, Shu; Kureishi, Yuka; Saito, Shohei; Yamaguchi, Shigehiro; Shinokubo, Hiroshi
        Organic Letters (2012), 14 (3), 866-869CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        A biphenyl-fused BODIPY was synthesized through a facile oxidative cyclization of peripheral aryl-substituents at the β-position of the BODIPY unit. The extended π-system of the fused BODIPY induces near-IR (NIR) absorption and strong π-π interactions in the solid state. These features are beneficial for the application of the dye as a functional material. The biphenyl-fused BODIPY dye was demonstrated to exhibit photocurrent conversion ability on the basis of its n-type semiconducting property.

        67
        Photostability studies of three new bicyclo-boron dipyrromethene difluoride dyes
        Sisk, Wade N.; Ono, Noboru; Yano, Tomoko; Wada, Mitsuo
        Dyes and Pigments (2002), 55 (2-3), 143-150CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        The photostabilities of three novel bicyclo-boron dipyrromethene difluoride dyes (bicyclo-BODIPY) in soln. were investigated by measuring the fluorescence intensity as a function of accumulated 532 nm laser pulses. At 10-6 M concn. 2-butanone and methanol solns. of the first 2 bicyclo-BODIPY dyes exhibited photodegrdn. half-lives within 25% of the photodegrdn. half-life for 1,3,5,7,8-pentamethyl-2,6,-di-tert-butylpyrromethene difluoroborate (PM-597). At 10-7 M the photostability of a 2-butanone soln. of the second bicyclo-BODIPY is only half that of PM-597. The first 2 bicyclo-BODIPY dyes demonstrated maxima in the fluorescence vs. accumulated pulses plots, attributed to a fluorescent benzo intermediate produced by a retro Diels-Alder reaction.

J. 2004, 10, 4853– 4871,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200400173
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        68
        Boron-diindomethene (BDI) dyes and their tetrahydrobicyclo precursors - en route to a new class of highly emissive fluorophores for the red spectral range
        Shen, Zhen; Roehr, Holger; Rurack, Knut; Uno, Hidemitsu; Spieles, Monika; Schulz, Burkhard; Reck, Guenter; Ono, Noboru
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2004), 10 (19), 4853-4871CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The x-ray crystallog., optical spectroscopic, and electrochem. properties of a newly synthesized class of boron-diindomethene (BDI) dyes and their tetrahydrobicyclo precursors (bc-BDP) are presented. The BDI chromophore was designed to show intensive absorption and strong fluorescence in an applicationally advantageous spectral range. Its modular architecture permits fusion of a second subunit, for example, a receptor moiety to the dye's core to yield directly linked yet perpendicularly prearranged composite systems. The synthesis was developed to allow facile tuning of the chromophore platform and to thus adjust its redox properties. X-ray anal. revealed a pronounced planarity of the chromophore in the case of the BDIs, which led to a remarkable close packing in the crystal of the simplest deriv. On the other hand, deviation from planarity was found for a diester-substituted bc-BDP benzocrown that exhibits a "butterfly"-like conformation in the crystal. Both families of dyes show charge- or electron-transfer-type fluorescence-quenching characteristics in polar solvents when equipped with a strong donor in the meso-position of the core. These processes can be utilized for signaling purposes if an appropriate receptor is introduced. Further modification of the chromophore can invoke such a guest-responsive intramol. quenching process, also for receptor groups of low electron d., for example, benzocrowns. In addn. to the design of various proto-type mols., a promising fluoroionophore for Na+ was obtained that absorbs and emits in the 650 nm region and shows a strong fluorescence enhancement upon analyte binding. Furthermore, investigation of the remarkable solvatokinetic fluorescence properties of the "butterfly"-like bc-BDP derivs. suggested that a second intrinsic nonradiative deactivation channel can play a role in the photophysics of boron-dipyrromethene dyes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXoslegu7g%253D&md5=f53034ed32c48e795f6bf2180a7c4e64
        open URL

        Okujima, T.; Tomimori, Y.; Nakamura, J.; Yamada, H.; Uno, H.; Ono, N. Synthesis of π-Expanded BODIPYs and Their Fluorescent Properties in The Visible–Near–Infrared Region. Tetrahedron 2010, 66, 6895– 6900,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2010.06.045

        69
        Synthesis of π-expanded BODIPYs and their fluorescent properties in the visible-near-infrared region
        Okujima, Tetsuo; Tomimori, Yuya; Nakamura, Jun; Yamada, Hiroko; Uno, Hidemitsu; Ono, Noboru
        Tetrahedron (2010), 66 (34), 6895-6900CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A series of π-expanded boron-dipyrromethenes (BODIPYs) fused with arom. rings at β,β-positions, such as benzene, acenaphthylene, and benzofluoranthene were prepd. by the reaction of BF3·OEt2 with bicyclo[2.2.2]octadiene-fused dipyrromethene and the subsequent retro Diels-Alder reaction. These BODIPYs exhibited the absorptions and the fluorescence emissions over wide range of visible-near-IR region at 500-800 nm. BODIPYs composed of two fluorantho[8,9-f]isoindoles absorbed and emitted at red-region over 750 nm with abs. fluorescence quantum yield (Φ f) of ca. 0.3, although they are unstable under air in room light. BODIPY composed fluorantho[8,9-f]isoindole and acenaphtho[1,2-c]pyrrole was stable and showed a bright fluorescence emission at 695 nm with high Φ f of 0.70.

        Yu, C.; Xu, Y.; Jiao, L.; Zhou, J.; Wang, Y.; Hao, E. Isoindole-BODIPY Dyes as Red to Near-Infrared Fluorophores. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 6437– 6442,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201200398
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        70
        Isoindole-BODIPY Dyes as Red to Near-Infrared Fluorophores
        Yu, Changjiang; Xu, Yajun; Jiao, Lijuan; Zhou, Jinyuan; Wang, Zhaoyun; Hao, Erhong
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (21), 6437-6442, S6437/1-S6437/78CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        We have successfully developed a facile one-pot synthesis of isoindole-BODIPY dyes based on nucleophilic substitution (SNAr) reaction of in situ formedchlorinated dipyrromethene by pyrrole. These novel isoindole-BODIPY dyes showed particularly useful optical properties,such as the long-wavelength, sharp absorption and fluorescence, high fluorescence quantum yields (up to 0.91), and high photostability. The wavelength is finely tuneable over a wide range (from 590 to 714 nm) by simple variation of substituent groups and through functionalization. The un-expected facile one-pot syntheses and the excellent photophys. properties of these isoindole-BODIPY dyes may render them potential applications in fluorescent labeling and imaging areas.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xlslyntb8%253D&md5=6a88b655d9139342ad5ad3cf4dbc7ba9

      71. 71
        Nagai, A.; Chujo, Y. Aromatic Ring-Fused BODIPY-Based Conjugated Polymers Exhibiting Narrow Near-Infrared Emission Bands. Macromolecules 2010, 43, 193– 200,  DOI: 10.1021/ma901449c
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        71
        Aromatic ring-fused BODIPY-based conjugated polymers exhibiting narrow near-infrared emission bands
        Nagai, Atsushi; Chujo, Yoshiki
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 43 (1), 193-200CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        Three conjugated copolymers, consisted of alternating p-phenylene-ethynylene and boron di(iso)indomethene units in the backbone, were synthesized via palladium-catalyzed Sonogashira coupling reaction of 1,4-diethynyl-2,5-dihexadecyloxybenzene and three diiodophenyl-fused blue, green, and purple BODIPY monomers. The structures and properties of the conjugated polymers were characterized by 1H NMR, 11B NMR, and Fourier transform IR spectroscopies, elemental anal., size-exclusion chromatog., UV-visible absorption spectroscopy, photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy, and theor. calcn. using the d.-functional theory (DFT) method. The polymers obtained were fusible and sol. in common org. solvents including THF, benzene, toluene, CHCl3, and CH2Cl2, etc. The incorporation of the indomethene monomers into the p-phenylene-ethynylene main chain led to red shifts in UV-absorption and PL spectra by extended π-conjugation of the copolymers in comparison with the monomers. Accordingly, the copolymers emitted in the range from deep-red to the near-IR region with emission spectral maxima at around 691-720 nm and exhibited high quantum yields (ΦF = 33-49%). The photostabilities of the polymers were examd. by monitoring decreases of the PL spectra under continuous UV irradn. using a UV lamp under aerobic conditions. Further, their thermal stabilities were also investigated by TGA measurement.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFWmur%252FO&md5=78e0e2762b2ee60eb2a469b5e7f3df36

        open URL
      73. 73
        Uppal, T.; Hu, X.; Fronczek, F. R.; Maschek, S.; Bobadova-Parvanova, P.; Vicente, M. G. H. Synthesis, Computational Modeling, and Properties of Benzo-Appended BODIPYs. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 3893– 3905,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201103002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        73
        Synthesis, Computational Modeling, and Properties of Benzo-Appended BODIPYs
        Uppal, Timsy; Hu, Xiaoke; Fronczek, Frank R.; Maschek, Stephanie; Bobadova-Parvanova, Petia; Vicente, M. Graca H.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (13), 3893-3905, S3893/1-S3893/64CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of new functionalized mono- and dibenzo-appended BODIPY dyes were synthesized from a common tetrahydroisoindole precursor following two different synthetic routes. Route A involved the assembly of the BODIPY core prior to aromatization, while in Route B the aromatization step was performed first. In general, Route A gave higher yields of the target dibenzo-BODIPYs, due to the ease of aromatization of the BODIPYs compared with the corresponding dipyrromethenes, probably due to their higher stability under the oxidative conditions (2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone in refluxing toluene). However, due to the slow oxidn. of highly electron-deficient BODIPY 3 c bearing a meso-C6F5 group, dibenzo-BODIPY 4 c was obtained, in 35 % overall from dipyrromethane, only by Route B. Computational calcns. performed at the 6-31G(d,p) level are in agreement with the exptl. results, showing similar relative energies for all reaction intermediates in both routes. In addn., BODIPY 3 c had the highest mol. electrostatic potential (MEPN), confirming its high electron deficiency and consequent resistance toward oxidn. X-ray analyses of eight BODIPYs and several intermediates show that benzannulation further enhances the planarity of these systems. The π-extended BODIPYs show strong red-shifted absorptions and emissions, about 50-60 nm per benzoannulated ring, at 589-658 and 596-680 nm, resp. In particular, db-BODIPY 4 c bearing a meso-C6F5 group showed the longest λmax of absorption and emission, along with the lowest fluorescence quantum yield (0.31 in CH2Cl2); on the other hand monobenzo-BODIPY 8 showed the highest quantum yield (0.99) of this series. Cellular investigations using human carcinoma HEp2 cells revealed high plasma membrane permeability for all dibenzo-BODIPYs, low dark- and photo-cytotoxicities and intracellular localization in the cell endoplasmic reticulum, in addn. to other organelles. Our studies indicate that benzo-appended BODIPYs, in particular the highly stable meso-substituted BODIPYs, are promising fluorophores for bioimaging applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XivV2ktrk%253D&md5=88854441f9e49e7f896f867a7621e339
        open URL
      74. 74
        Treibs, A.; Kreuzer, F.-H. Difluorboryl-Komplexe von Di-und Tripyrrylmethenen. Justus Liebigs Ann. Chem. 1968, 718, 208– 223,  DOI: 10.1002/jlac.19687180119
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Difluoroboryl complexes of di- and tripyrrylmethenes
        Treibs, Alfred; Kreuzer, Franz H.
        Justus Liebigs Annalen der Chemie (1968), 718 (), 208-23CODEN: JLACBF; ISSN:0075-4617.
        Di- and tripyrrylmethenes gave with BF3 in the presence of tertiary bases fluorescent difluoroboryl complexes. Thus, N,N'-difluoroboryl-3,3',5,5'-tetramethyl-2,2'-dipyrrylmethene was prepd. from 3,3',5,5'-tetramethyl-2,2'-dipyrrylmethene and BF3·Et2O in the presence of Et3N. The complexes with neg. substituents in the pyrrole ring gave alkali salts. Al gave similar, but very unstable complexes. Tris(2-methyl-3-ethoxycarbonyl-5-pyrryl)methene was prepd. from 2-methyl-3-ethoxycarbonylpyrrole and oxalyl chloride.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF1MXjslGruw%253D%253D&md5=b4b2fc5f8181a01b4022b890a8c38789
        open URL
      75. 75
        Didukh, N. O.; Yakubovskyi, V. P.; Zatsikha, Y. V.; Nemykin, V. N.; Kovtun, Y. P. meso-Nitromethyl-Substituted BODIPYs - A new type of water switchable fluorogenic dyes useful for further core modifications. Dyes Pigm. 2018, 149, 774– 782,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2017.11.037
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        75
        meso-Nitromethyl-Substituted BODIPYs - A new type of water switchable fluorogenic dyes useful for further core modifications
        Didukh, Natalia O.; Yakubovskyi, Viktor P.; Zatsikha, Yuriy V.; Nemykin, Victor N.; Kovtun, Yuriy P.
        Dyes and Pigments (2018), 149 (), 774-782CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A two-step synthetic pathway for direct introduction of the nitromethyl functional group at the meso-position of BODIPY core was explored using a no. of meso-unsubstituted BODIPY platforms. Spectral properties of the resulting meso-nitromethyl contg. BODIPYs was sensitive to the pH change as well as to the presence of water in org. solvents. Meso-nitromethyl group can be used for further modification of the BODIPY core via redn. or condensation reactions. DFT-PCM and TDDFT-PCM calcns. correlate well with the exptl. data and explain the obsd. spectral properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvFWgsLfE&md5=13a9af7a7bfc8a03f2cf12fc124fb9bb
        open URL
      76. 76
        Beh, M. H. R.; Douglas, K. I. B.; House, K. T. E.; Murphy, A. C.; Sinclair, J. S. T.; Thompson, A. Robust synthesis of F-BODIPYs. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2016, 14, 11473– 11479,  DOI: 10.1039/C6OB02238C
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        open URL
      77. 77
        Falk, H.; Schoppel, G. The chemistry of bile pigments. LXXXIV. Preparation and luminescence of bichromophoric 5-aryldipyrrin derivatives. Monatsh. Chem. 1990, 121, 67– 76,  DOI: 10.1007/BF00810296
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        The chemistry of bile pigments. LXXXIV. Preparation and luminescence of bichromophoric 5-aryldipyrrin derivatives
        Falk, Heinz; Schoppel, Gerhard
        Monatshefte fuer Chemie (1990), 121 (1), 67-76CODEN: MOCMB7; ISSN:0026-9247.
        Dipyrrins RH, RPh, RC6H4CHO-3, m-R2C6H2, p-R2C6H4 (R1 = H, BF2) and their Zn complexes were prepd. Their absorption and fluorescence spectra are compared. The conformations of these compds. are analyzed using the ring current model and absorption spectra. Dipole-dipole type transfer of excitation energy is discussed as a main photophys. channel in these compds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXltFCqsrg%253D&md5=d9305355a50a78e98b44a04d9e8592e8
        open URL
      78. 78
        Buyukcakir, O.; Bozdemir, O. A.; Kolemen, S.; Erbas, S.; Akkaya, E. U. Tetrastyryl-BODIPY Dyes: Convenient Synthesis and Characterization of Elusive Near IR Fluorophores. Org. Lett. 2009, 11, 4644– 4647,  DOI: 10.1021/ol9019056
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        Tetrastyryl-Bodipy dyes: Convenient synthesis and characterization of elusive near IR fluorophores
        Buyukcakir, Onur; Bozdemir, O. Altan; Kolemen, Safacan; Erbas, Sundus; Akkaya, Engin U.
        Organic Letters (2009), 11 (20), 4644-4647CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        1,3,5,7-Tetramethyl-Bodipy derivs. undergo Knoevenagel-type condensations with arom. aldehydes to ultimately yield tetrastyryl-Bodipy derivs. The resulting dyes absorb and emit strongly in the near-IR. As the versatility of the Bodipy dyes are fully appreciated, these new tetrastyryl dyes are likely to be featured in a variety of functional supramol. systems.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFCjt7zI&md5=f1a46d7fc078a7a278ae08bee14ffa56
        open URL
      79. 79
        Bura, T.; Hablot, D.; Ziessel, R. Fluorescent Boron Dipyrromethene (BODIPY) Dyes Having Two and Four Vinyl Residues. Tetrahedron Lett. 2011, 52, 2370– 2374,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tetlet.2011.02.094
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        open URL
      80. 80
        Bura, T.; Retailleau, P.; Ulrich, G.; Ziessel, R. Highly Substituted BODIPY Dyes with Spectroscopic Features Sensitive to The Environment. J. Org. Chem. 2011, 76, 1109– 1117,  DOI: 10.1021/jo102203f
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        80
        Highly Substituted Bodipy Dyes with Spectroscopic Features Sensitive to the Environment
        Bura, Thomas; Retailleau, Pascal; Ulrich, Gilles; Ziessel, Raymond
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2011), 76 (4), 1109-1117CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A general method for the synthesis of butterfly-shaped difluoroboradiaza-s-indacenes with different substituents has been developed. The mixed AB dye was produced in two successive Knoevenagel reactions involving first 4-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde and second 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde. Two pathways to A2B2 and ABCD derivs. were investigated starting from a tetramethyl-substituted Bodipy. The pivotal compd. is a bis-styryl phenol deriv. also produced by a Knoevenagel reaction without the need to protect the phenol functions. Methylation of the phenol functions provides mono- and bis-derivs. which have been used to construct tetrastyryl A2B2 and ABCD derivs., resp. Stepwise alkylation of the monomethoxyphenol dye provided a mixed dye that was converted to a tris-substituted compd., isolated as a mixt. of regioisomers. The fourth styryl function was introduced by using 4-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde and forcing conditions. These highly colored dyes display outstanding optical properties with absorption wavelengths spanning from 573 to 718 nm and emission wavelengths from 585 to 800 nm. The high quantum yields, nanosecond excited state lifetimes, and weak Stokes shifts are typical of singlet emitters. The presence of both dimethylamino and phenol residues in some of these dyes makes them sensitive to acids and bases, allowing the tuning of the optical properties over a large wavelength range as a function of pH. A unique three-color ratiometric pH sensor based on both absorption and fluorescence has been characterized and studied in detail. The tris- and tetra-substitution of the Me groups by vinyl residues induces a weaker bathochromic shift than that due to mono- and disubstitution. Consequently, replacing an alkoxy function by a dimethylamino moiety in the tetra-substituted derivs. has little effect on the spectroscopic features.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmslCmsA%253D%253D&md5=a380e519cff702944add01c658528a28
        open URL
      81. 81
        Cidlina, A.; Miletin, M.; Fathi-Rasekh, M.; Nemykin, V. N.; Zimcik, P.; Novakova, V. OFF-ON-OFF Red-Emitting Fluorescent Indicators for a Narrow pH Window. Chem. - Eur. J. 2017, 23, 1795– 1804,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201604978
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        81
        OFF-ON-OFF Red-Emitting Fluorescent Indicators for a Narrow pH Window
        Cidlina, Antonin; Miletin, Miroslav; Fathi-Rasekh, Mahtab; Nemykin, Victor N.; Zimcik, Petr; Novakova, Veronika
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (8), 1795-1804CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A unique combination of two independent mechanisms of fluorescence quenching, namely intramol. charge transfer (ICT) from a peripheral donor and protonation of azomethine nitrogen atoms in zinc tetrapyrazinoporphyrazines (TPyzPz), provides a new possibility for sensing pH in a specific range. The pH selectivity was controlled by the different basicities of the donor for ICT (dimethylaminoaryl), which was connected to the macrocycle by π-extended linkers of different lengths. ICT and protonation have been studied in detail by photophys., spectral (UV/Vis and MCD spectra), and electrochem. measurements, and further supported by theor. calcns. (DFT, TDDFT). The pH-sensing properties of the TPyzPzs have been investigated in THF and in water after anchoring the TPyzPzs to liposomes. The salient pKa values were around 1.3 (azomethine nitrogen) and 2.29-4.76 (donor for ICT). The lead indicators (sensing over a pH range of 1.0-2.5) with fairly steep sensing profiles exhibited increases in fluorescence between the OFF/ON states of more than 20-fold and strong absorption in the red region (Q-band max. >650 nm, ε≈2×106 m-1 cm-1).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFamtLjP&md5=04f2a99cdbb91d0cdab19171ed9568b9
        open URL
      82. 82
        Tao, J. M.; Perdew, J. P.; Staroverov, V. N.; Scuseria, G. E. Climbing the density functional ladder: Nonempirical meta-generalized gradient approximation designed for molecules and solids. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2003, 91, 146401,  DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.91.146401
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        82
        Climbing the Density Functional Ladder: Nonempirical Meta-Generalized Gradient Approximation Designed for Molecules and Solids
        Tao, Jianmin; Perdew, John P.; Staroverov, Viktor N.; Scuseria, Gustavo E.
        Physical Review Letters (2003), 91 (14), 146401/1-146401/4CODEN: PRLTAO; ISSN:0031-9007. (American Physical Society)
        The electron d., its gradient, and the Kohn-Sham orbital kinetic energy d. are the local ingredients of a meta-generalized gradient approxn. (meta-GGA). We construct a meta-GGA d. functional for the exchange-correlation energy that satisfies exact constraints without empirical parameters. The exchange and correlation terms respect two paradigms: one- or two-electron densities and slowly varying densities, and so describe both mols. and solids with high accuracy, as shown by extensive numerical tests. This functional completes the third rung of "Jacob's ladder" of approxns., above the local spin d. and GGA rungs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXnvVKmur4%253D&md5=ee0673dbddc2c14c6bdc2eddf4945d04
        open URL
      83. 83
        Tomasi, J.; Mennucci, B.; Cammi, R. Quantum mechanical continuum solvation models. Chem. Rev. 2005, 105, 2999– 3093,  DOI: 10.1021/cr9904009
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        83
        Quantum Mechanical Continuum Solvation Models
        Tomasi, Jacopo; Mennucci, Benedetta; Cammi, Roberto
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2005), 105 (8), 2999-3093CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVynurc%253D&md5=462420dd18b3006ee63d1298b66db247

      84. 84
        McLean, A. D.; Chandler, G. S. Contracted Gaussian basis sets for molecular calculations. I. Second row atoms, Z= 11–18. J. Chem. Phys. 1980, 72, 5639– 5648,  DOI: 10.1063/1.438980
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        84
        Contracted Gaussian basis sets for molecular calculations. I. Second row atoms, Z = 11-18
        McLean, A. D.; Chandler, G. S.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1980), 72 (10), 5639-48CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        Contracted Gaussian basis sets for mol. calcns. are derived from uncontracted (12,8) and (12,9) sets for the neutral second row atoms, Z = 11-18, and for the neg. ions P-, S-, and Cl-. Calcns. on Na...2p63p, 2P and Mg...2p63s3p, 3P are used to derive contracted Gaussian functions to describe the 3p orbital in these atoms, necessary in mol. applications. The derived basis sets range from minimal, through double-zeta, to the largest set which has a triple-zeta basis for the 3p orbital, double-zeta for the remaining. Where necessary to avoid unacceptable energy losses in at. wave functions expanded in the contracted Gaussians, a given uncontracted Gaussian function is used in two contracted functions. These tabulations provide a hierarchy of basis sets to be used in designing a convergent sequence of mol. computations, and to establish the reliability of the mol. properties under study.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3cXksFCnu7c%253D&md5=c273cc5d7ac2eef1d9c13825d81c68ac
        open URL
      85. 85
        Frisch, M. J.; Trucks, G. W.; Schlegel, H. B.; Scuseria, G. E. Gaussian 09, revision D.1; Gaussian, Inc.: Wallingford, CT, 2009.
        Google Scholar

        Tenderholt, A. L. QMForge, version 2.1; Stanford University: Stanford, CA, USA.

      87. 87
        Sheldrick, G. M. Crystal Structure Refinement with SHELXL. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Found. Crystallogr. 2008, A64, 112– 122,  DOI: 10.1107/S0108767307043930
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        87
        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
        open URL
